","hash":"8199454090eefb7d96e7b67a65c7da4e","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0c410037-e24e-4f71-8c62-7b10221acc2b","title":"080 - All Data AI with Dr. Andrew Fitzgibbon","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_080_fitzgibbon.mp3","published":"2019-06-12T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

You may not know who Dr. Andrew Fitzgibbon is, but if you‚Äôve watched a TV show or movie in the last two decades, you‚Äôve probably seen some of his work. An expert in 3D computer vision and graphics, and head of the new All Data AI group at Microsoft Research Cambridge, Dr. Fitzgibbon was instrumental in the development of Boujou, an Emmy Award-winning 3D camera tracker that lets filmmakers place virtual props, like the floating candles in Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry, into live-action footage. But that was just his warm-up act.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Fitzgibbon tells us what he‚Äôs been working on since the Emmys in 2002, including body- and hand-tracking for powerhouse Microsoft technologies like Kinect for Xbox 360 and HoloLens, explains how research on dolphins helped build mathematical models for the human hand, and reminds us, once again, that the ‚Äúsecret sauce‚Äù to most innovation is often just good, old-fashioned hard work.

","hash":"d82c57e17e833501e6b4a35133da88e0","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"2b13891d-81f1-47e8-9974-9f854938e9df","title":"079 - Making the most of micro-moments with Dr. Shamsi Iqbal","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_079_iqbal.mp3","published":"2019-06-05T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôve recently found it more difficult to focus your attention for a lengthy stretch of time in order to get a complex task done‚Ä¶ or worse, found it difficult even to find a lengthy stretch of time in which to try, you‚Äôre not alone. And actually, you‚Äôre in luck. Dr. Shamsi Iqbal, a senior researcher in the Information and Data Sciences group at Microsoft Research, wants to help you manage your attention better and be more productive at the same time. And she‚Äôs using technology to do it!

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Iqbal tells us about her work in the field of micro-productivity, a line of research that takes aim at the short spurts of time she calls micro-moments that we otherwise might have considered too short to get anything useful done. She also explains why distraction can be good for us and gives us some advice on how to make the most of our cognitive resources, whether by setting aside time to tackle big tasks in the traditional way or by breaking them down into micro-tasks‚Ä¶ and ‚Äúoutsourcing‚Äù them to ourselves!

","hash":"a3d81b6d4925d7a82cb0ccb83a3bf5de","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"36f2e450-900f-4e73-879e-38f019b7b8af","title":"078 - Machine teaching with Dr. Patrice Simard","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_078_simard.mp3","published":"2019-05-29T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Machine learning is a powerful tool that enables computers to learn by observing the world, recognizing patterns and self-training via experience. Much like humans. But while machines perform well when they can extract knowledge from large amounts of labeled data, their learning outcomes remain vastly inferior to humans when data is limited. That‚Äôs why Dr. Patrice Simard, Distinguished Engineer and head of the Machine Teaching group at Microsoft, is using actual teachers to help machines learn, and enable them to extract knowledge from humans rather than just data.

\n

Today, Dr. Simard tells us why he believes any task you can teach to a human, you should be able to teach to a machine; explains how machines can exploit the human ability to decompose and explain concepts to train ML models more efficiently and less expensively; and gives us an innovative vision of how, when a human teacher and a machine learning model work together in a real-time interactive process, domain experts can leverage the power of machine learning without machine learning expertise.

","hash":"75f2ce03f3d060e31ad10207e2a59c81","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"3f797c36-749b-4d0b-8f3d-5c92d4054523","title":"077 - The productive software engineer with Dr. Tom Zimmermann","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_077_zimmermann.mp3","published":"2019-05-22T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôre in software development, Dr. Tom Zimmermann, a senior researcher at Microsoft Research in Redmond, wants you to be more productive, and he‚Äôs here to help. How, you might ask? Well, while productivity can be hard to measure, his research in the Empirical Software Engineering group is attempting to do just that by using insights from actual data, rather than just gut feelings, to improve the software development process.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Zimmermann talks about why we need to rethink productivity in software engineering, explains why work environments matter, tells us how AI and machine learning are impacting traditional software workflows, and reveals the difference between a typical day and a good day in the life of a software developer, and what it would take to make a good day typical!

","hash":"b134b3b2bee9c4b24f9512fc937e5269","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"135bca83-b8d2-4fcc-8313-971159ed8eb7","title":"076 - Speech and language: the crown jewel of AI with Dr. Xuedong Huang","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_076_huang.mp3","published":"2019-05-15T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When was the last time you had a meaningful conversation with your computer‚Ä¶ and felt like it truly understood you? Well, if Dr. Xuedong Huang, a Microsoft Technical Fellow and head of Microsoft‚Äôs Speech and Language group, is successful, you will. And if his track record holds true, it‚Äôll be sooner than you think!

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Huang talks about his role as Microsoft‚Äôs Chief Speech Scientist, gives us some inside details on the latest milestones in speech and language technology, and explains how mastering speech recognition, translation and conversation will move machines further along the path from ‚Äúperceptive AI‚Äù to ‚Äúcognitive AI‚Äù and that much closer to truly human intelligence.

","hash":"b98d1726629a07e9760c68ce34dd4676","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"05ae5ba0-c1a1-4288-9c81-635c07d25df1","title":"075 - Reinforcement learning for the real world with Dr. John Langford and Rafah Hosn","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_075_langford_hosn.mp3","published":"2019-05-08T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. John Langford, a partner researcher in the Machine Learning group at Microsoft Research New York City, is a reinforcement learning expert who is working, in his own words, to solve machine learning. Rafah Hosn, also of MSR New York, is a principal program manager who‚Äôs working to take that work to the world. If that sounds like big thinking in the Big Apple, well, New York City has always been a ‚Äúgo big, or go home‚Äù kind of town, and MSR NYC is a ‚Äúgo big, or go home‚Äù kind of lab.

\n

Today, Dr. Langford explains why online reinforcement learning is critical to solving machine learning and how moving from the current foundation of a Markov decision process toward a contextual bandit future might be part of the solution. Rafah Hosn talks about why it‚Äôs important, from a business perspective, to move RL agents out of simulated environments and into the open world, and gives us an under-the-hood look at the product side of MSR‚Äôs ‚Äúresearch, incubate, transfer‚Äù process, focusing on real world reinforcement learning which, at Microsoft, is now called Azure Cognitive Services Personalizer.

","hash":"498a036202c4a42eafe2ff4875f05f75","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"fa617142-a834-4669-af59-40d6fa910917","title":"074 - CHI squared with Dr. Ken Hinckley and Dr. Meredith Ringel Morris","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_074_Hinkley_Morris_2.mp3","published":"2019-05-01T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you want to know what‚Äôs going on in the world of human computer interaction research, or what‚Äôs new at the CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, you should hang out with Dr. Ken Hinckley, a principal researcher and research manager in the EPIC group at Microsoft Research, and Dr. Merrie Ringel Morris, a principal researcher and research manager in the Ability group. Both are prolific HCI researchers who are seeking, from different angles, to augment the capability of technologies and improve the experiences people have with them.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, we get to hang out with both Dr. Hinckley and Dr. Morris as they talk about life at the intersection of hardware, software and human potential, discuss how computers can enhance human lives, especially in some of the most marginalized populations, and share their unique approaches to designing and building technologies that really work for people and for society.

","hash":"0076e927b489c5fe89b6fdc0f72d49f4","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"fa90c5ee-4e00-4dcc-b46f-fb255c7e2f8d","title":"073 - Froid and the relational database query quandry with Dr. Karthik Ramachandra","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_073_ramachandra.mp3","published":"2019-04-24T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

In the world of relational databases, structured query language, or SQL, has long been King of the Queries, primarily because of its ubiquity and unparalleled performance. But many users prefer a mix of imperative programming, along with declarative SQL, because its user-defined functions (or UDFs) allow for good software engineering practices like modularity, readability and re-usability. Sadly, these benefits have traditionally come with a huge performance penalty, rendering them impractical in most situations. That bothered Dr. Karthik Ramachandra, a Senior Applied Scientist at Microsoft Research India, so he‚Äôs spent a great deal of his career working on improving an imperative complement to SQL in database systems.

\n

Today, Dr. Ramachandra gives us an overview of the historic trade-offs between declarative and imperative programming paradigms, tells us some fantastic stories, including The Tale of Two Engineers and The UDF Story, Parts 1 and 2, and introduces us to Froid ‚Äì that‚Äôs F-R-O-I-D, not the Austrian psychoanalyst ‚Äì which is an extensible, language-agnostic framework for optimizing imperative functions in databases, offering the benefits of UDFs without sacrificing performance.

","hash":"5cea65968851148d22ce91d594b45226","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"5d570cf6-6ba1-49bd-b548-1f28efd79f07","title":"072 - AI for Earth with Dr. Lucas Joppa","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_072_joppa.mp3","published":"2019-04-17T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

We hear a lot these days about ‚ÄúAI for good‚Äù and the efforts of many companies to harness the power of artificial intelligence to solve some of our biggest environmental challenges. It‚Äôs rare, however, that you find a company willing to bring its environmental bona fides all the way to the C Suite. Well, meet Dr. Lucas Joppa. A former environmental and computer science researcher at MSR who was tapped in 2017 to become the company‚Äôs first Chief Environmental Scientist, Dr. Joppa is now the Chief Environmental Officer at Microsoft, another first, and is responsible for managing the company‚Äôs overall environmental sustainability efforts from operations to policy to technology.

\n

Today, Dr. Joppa shares how his love for nature and the joy of discovery actually helped shape his career path, and tells us all about AI for Earth, a multi-year, multi-million dollar initiative to deploy the full scale of Microsoft‚Äôs products, policies and partnerships across four key areas of agriculture, water, biodiversity and climate, and transform the way society monitors, models, and ultimately manages Earth‚Äôs natural resources.

","hash":"83e6de7c4fa02bd50c76d1a0fe33fc4a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"d4f7ab9e-ef2f-40a2-aae2-5cc5607774a1","title":"071 - Holograms, spatial anchors and the future of computer vision with Dr. Marc Pollefeys","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_071_pollefeys.mp3","published":"2019-04-10T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

Dr. Marc Pollefeys is a Professor of Computer Science at ETH Zurich, a Partner Director of Science for Microsoft, and the Director of a new Microsoft Mixed Reality and AI lab in Switzerland. He‚Äôs a leader in the field of computer vision research, but it‚Äôs hard to pin down whether his work is really about the future of computer vision, or about a vision of future computers. Arguably, it‚Äôs both!

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Pollefeys brings us up to speed on the latest in computer vision research, including his innovative work with Azure Spatial Anchors, tells us how devices like Kinect and HoloLens may have cut their teeth in gaming, but turned out to be game changers for both research and industrial applications, and explains how, while it‚Äôs still early days now, in the future, you‚Äôre much more likely to put your computer on your head than on your desk or your lap.

","hash":"bdd6b115550afd334dd99817259f40a0","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"fac104c5-477a-4a56-bb85-7193e5cacdc7","title":"070 - Enabling design with Ann Paradiso","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_070_paradiso.mp3","published":"2019-04-03T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Ann Paradiso is an interaction designer and the Principal User Experience Designer for the NExT Enable group at Microsoft Research. She‚Äôs also the epitome of a phrase she often uses to describe other people: a force of nature. Together with a diverse array of team members and collaborators, many of whom have ALS or other conditions that affect mobility and speech, Ann works on new interaction paradigms for assistive technologies hoping to make a more bespoke approach to technology solutions accessible, at scale, to the people who need it most.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Ann tells us all about life in the extreme constraint design lane, explains what a PALS is, and tells us some incredibly entertaining stories about how the eye tracking technology behind the Eye Controlled Wheelchair and the Hands-Free Music Project has made its way from Microsoft‚Äôs campus to some surprising events around the country, including South by Southwest and Mardi Gras.

","hash":"1647d8630285ef1a6103d20b08b5e6bf","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"844abbf2-1412-4894-9aa5-df64dddf4b9d","title":"069 - All about automated machine learning with Dr. Nicolo Fusi","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_069_fusi_RERUN.mp3","published":"2019-03-27T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in September, 2018:

\n

You may have heard the phrase, necessity is the mother of invention, but for Dr. Nicolo Fusi, a researcher at the Microsoft Research lab in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the mother of his invention wasn‚Äôt so much necessity as it was boredom: the special machine learning boredom of manually fine-tuning models and hyper-parameters that can eat up tons of human and computational resources, but bring no guarantee of a good result. His solution? Automate machine learning with a meta-model that figures out what other models are doing, and then predicts how they‚Äôll work on a given dataset.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Fusi gives us an inside look at Automated Machine Learning ‚Äì Microsoft‚Äôs version of the industry‚Äôs AutoML technology ‚Äì and shares the story of how an idea he had while working on a gene editing problem with CRISPR/Cas9 turned into a bit of a machine learning side quest and, ultimately, a surprisingly useful instantiation of Automated Machine Learning ‚Äì now a feature of Azure Machine Learning ‚Äì that reduces dependence on intuition and takes some of the tedium out of data science at the same time.

","hash":"1582a645e27fcf87455d3e706dcee663","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ca39df4d-bbad-4011-9660-62e6502fc9bb","title":"068 - Project Triton and the physics of sound with Dr. Nikunj Raghuvanshi","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_068_raghuvanshi.mp3","published":"2019-03-20T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôve ever played video games, you know that for the most part, they look a lot better than they sound. That‚Äôs largely due to the fact that audible sound waves are much longer ‚Äì and a lot more crafty ‚Äì than visual light waves, and therefore, much more difficult to replicate in simulated environments. But Dr. Nikunj Raghuvanshi, a Senior Researcher in the Interactive Media Group at Microsoft Research, is working to change that by bringing the quality of game audio up to speed with the quality of game video. He wants you to hear how sound really travels ‚Äì in rooms, around corners, behind walls, out doors ‚Äì and he‚Äôs using computational physics to do it.

\n

Today, Dr. Raghuvanshi talks about the unique challenges of simulating realistic sound on a budget (both money and CPU), explains how classic ideas in concert hall acoustics need a fresh take for complex games like Gears of War, reveals the computational secret sauce you need to deliver the right sound at the right time, and tells us about Project Triton, an acoustic system that models how real sound waves behave in 3-D game environments to makes us believe with our ears as well as our eyes.

","hash":"36018634508c1e897129fa46fd61cd9a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"2d2770d8-6940-4bd9-9b16-5b13303139c5","title":"067 - Programming biology with Dr. Andrew Phillips","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_067_phillips.mp3","published":"2019-03-13T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When we think of information processing systems, we often think of computers, but we ourselves are made up of information processing systems ‚Äì trillions of them ‚Äì also known as the cells in our bodies. While these cells are robust, they‚Äôre also extraordinarily complex and not altogether predictable. Wouldn‚Äôt it be great, asks Dr. Andrew Phillips, head of the Biological Computation Group at Microsoft Research in Cambridge, if we could figure out exactly how these building blocks of life work and harness their power with the rigor and predictability of computer science? To answer that, he‚Äôs spent a good portion of his career working to develop a system of intelligence that can, literally, program biology.

\n

Today, Dr. Phillips talks about the challenges and rewards inherent in reverse engineering biological systems to see how they perform information processing. He also explains what we can learn from stressed out bacteria, and tells us about Station B, a new end-to-end platform his team is working on that aims to reduce the trial and error nature of lab experiments and help scientists turn biological cells into super-factories that could solve some of the most challenging problems in medicine, agriculture, the environment and more.

","hash":"f9dd0fa7a23b2bf775109ab80958137d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"3e5c289c-843c-4882-92d8-a22306ad2583","title":"066 (rerun) - Cryptography for the post-quantum world with Dr. Brian LaMacchia","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_066_LaMachia_RERUN.mp3","published":"2019-03-06T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in August of 2018.

\n

You know those people who work behind the scenes to make sure nothing bad happens to you, and if they‚Äôre really good, you never know who they are because nothing bad happens to you? Well, meet one of those people. Dr. Brian LaMacchia is a Distinguished Engineer and he heads up the Security and Cryptography Group at Microsoft Research. It‚Äôs his job to make sure ‚Äì using up-to-the-minute math ‚Äì that you‚Äôre safe and secure online, both now, and in the post-quantum world to come.

Today, Dr. LaMacchia gives us an inside look at the world of cryptography and the number theory behind it, explains what happens when good algorithms go bad, and tells us why, even though cryptographically relevant quantum computers are still decades away, we need to start developing quantum-resistant algorithms right now.

\n

¬†

","hash":"74ced685c48b3fdc201ec9039d2aeb3d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"08f04911-702f-4e67-9a77-a33373527981","title":"065 - Securing the vote with Dr. Josh Benaloh","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_065_benaloh.mp3","published":"2019-02-27T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôve ever wondered why, in the age of the internet, we still don‚Äôt hold our elections online, you need to spend more time with Dr. Josh Benaloh, Senior Cryptographer at Microsoft Research in Redmond. Josh knows a lot about elections, and even more about homomorphic encryption, the mathematical foundation behind the end-to-end verifiable election systems that can dramatically improve election integrity today and perhaps move us toward wide-scale online voting in the future.

\n

Today, Dr. Benaloh gives us a brief but fascinating history of elections, explains how the trade-offs among privacy, security and verifiability make the relatively easy math of elections such a hard problem for the internet, and tells the story of how the University of Michigan fight song forced the cancellation of an internet voting pilot.

","hash":"f56a45e34e59cf88d67ba4b91001d483","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"5aaa8b96-7c44-47b1-87b5-238d75023c0d","title":"064 - Talking with machines with Dr. Layla El Asri","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_064_el_asri.mp3","published":"2019-02-20T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Humans are unique in their ability to learn from, understand the world through and communicate with language‚Ä¶ Or are they? Perhaps not for long, if Dr. Layla El Asri, a Research Manager at Microsoft Research Montreal, has a say in it. She wants you to be able to talk to your machine just like you‚Äôd talk to another person. That‚Äôs the easy part. The hard part is getting your machine to understand and talk back to you like it‚Äôs that other person.

\n

Today, Dr. El Asri talks about the particular challenges she and other scientists face in building sophisticated dialogue systems that lay the foundation for talking machines. She also explains how reinforcement learning, in the form of a text game generator called TextWorld, is helping us get there, and relates a fascinating story from more than fifty years ago that reveals some of the safeguards necessary to ensure that when we design machines specifically to pass the Turing test, we design them in an ethical and responsible way.

","hash":"c80034305e50412d9143ee472e04f17f","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ffdfb06d-eaf0-4a72-ba99-1222d0858774","title":"063 - Competing in the X Games of machine learning with Dr. Manik Varma","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_063_varma.mp3","published":"2019-02-13T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If every question in life could be answered by choosing from just a few options, machine learning would be pretty simple, and life for machine learning researchers would be pretty sweet. Unfortunately, in both life and machine learning, things are a bit more complicated. That‚Äôs why Dr. Manik Varma, Principal Researcher at MSR India, is developing extreme classification systems to answer multiple-choice questions that have millions of possible options and help people find what they are looking for online more quickly, more accurately and less expensively.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Varma tells us all about extreme classification (including where in the world you might actually run into 10 or 100 million options), reveals how his Parabel and Slice algorithms are making high quality recommendations in milliseconds, and proves, with both his life and his work, that being blind need not be a barrier to extreme accomplishment.

","hash":"d7a3d71f69e446bf994e12d86d0aa267","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"5743144b-cbd7-457a-9672-887ec77ab3cd","title":"062 - Putting the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù in human computer interaction with Haiyan Zhang","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_062_Zhang-3.mp3","published":"2019-02-06T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Haiyan Zhang is a designer, technologist and maker of things (really cool technical things) who currently holds the unusual title of Innovation Director at the Microsoft Research lab in Cambridge, England. There, she applies her unusual skillset to a wide range of unusual solutions to real-life problems, many of which draw on novel applications of gaming technology in serious areas like healthcare.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Haiyan talks about her unique ‚Äúbrain hack‚Äù approach to the human-centered design process, and discusses a wide range of projects, from the connected play experience of Zanzibar, to Fizzyo, which turns laborious breathing exercises for children with cystic fibrosis into a video game, to Project Emma, an application of haptic vibration technology that, somewhat curiously, offsets the effects of tremors caused by Parkinson‚Äôs disease.

","hash":"77257434fadfb4b20faaa2414e896ef5","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"4ccb2817-a5ab-465f-8350-e9fe910d18c9","title":"061 - Enable(ing) people to do more with Dr. Rico Malvar","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_061_malvar.mp3","published":"2019-01-30T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

From his deep technical roots as a principal researcher and founder of the Communications, Collaboration and Signal Processing group at MSR, through his tenure as Managing Director of the lab in Redmond, to his current role as Distinguished Engineer, Chief Scientist for Microsoft Research and manager of the MSR NExT Enable group, Dr. Rico Malvar has seen ‚Äì and pretty well done ‚Äì it all.

\n

Today, Dr. Malvar recalls his early years at a fledgling Microsoft Research, talks about the exciting work he oversees now, explains why designing with the user is as important as designing for the user, and tells us how a challenge from an ex-football player with ALS led to a prize winning hackathon project and produced the core technology that allows you to type on a keyboard without your hands and drive a wheelchair with your eyes.

","hash":"2454b42d8bf3bd33cd12d7296ff42938","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"9c82240e-850d-46c2-9cd4-a8721a1dfcfa","title":"060 - Empowering people with AI with Dr. Cecily Morrison","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_060_morrison.mp3","published":"2019-01-23T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

You never know how an incident in your own life might inspire a breakthrough in science, but Dr. Cecily Morrison, a researcher in the Human Computer Interaction group at Microsoft Research Cambridge, can attest to how even unexpected events can cause us to see things through a different ‚Äì more inclusive ‚Äì lens and, ultimately, give rise to innovations in research that impact everyone.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Morrison gives us an overview of what she calls the ‚Äúpillars‚Äù of inclusive design, shares how her research is positively impacting people with health issues and disabilities, and tells us how having a child born with blindness put her in touch with a community of people she would otherwise never have met, and on the path to developing Project Torino, an inclusive physical programming language for children with visual impairments.

","hash":"53448c3b6b6bce3fa7878c79088befe4","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"2964e351-faa7-4a86-b230-072b4641572f","title":"059 - Building contextually intelligent assistants with Dr. Paul Bennett","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_059_bennett.mp3","published":"2019-01-16T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

The entertainment industry has long offered us a vision of the perfect personal assistant: one that not only meets our stated needs but anticipates needs we didn‚Äôt even know we had. But these uber-assistants, from the preternaturally prescient Radar O‚ÄôReilly in the TV show M.A.S.H. to Tony Stark‚Äôs digital know-and-do-it-all Jarvis in Iron Man, have always lived in the realm of fiction or science fiction. That could all change, if Dr. Paul Bennett, Principal Researcher and Research Manager of the Information and Data Sciences group at Microsoft Research, has anything to say about it. He and his team are working to make machines ‚Äúcalendar and email aware,‚Äù moving intelligent assistance into the realm of science and onto your workstation.

\n

Today, Dr. Bennett brings us up to speed on the science of contextually intelligent assistants, explains how what we think our machines can do actually shapes what we expect them to do, and shares how current research in machine learning and data science is helping machines reason on our behalf in the quest to help us find the right information effortlessly.

","hash":"77d9ee88750e4f599f744c968da9de16","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"a56ba36b-dc14-431b-8160-15c24c10ccff","title":"058 - Scaling the Everest of software security with Dr. Jonathan Protzenko","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_058_protzenko.mp3","published":"2019-01-09T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When people first started making software, computers were relatively rare and there was no internet, so programming languages were designed to get the job done quickly and run efficiently, with little thought for security. But software is everywhere now, from our desktops to our cars, from the cloud to the internet of things. That‚Äôs why Dr. Jonathan Protzenko, a researcher in the RiSE ‚Äì or Research in Software Engineering ‚Äì group at Microsoft Research, is working on designing better software tools in order to make our growing software ecosystem safer and more secure.

\n

Today, Dr. Protzenko talks about what‚Äôs wrong with software (and why it‚Äôs vitally important to get it right), explains why there are so many programming languages (and tells us about a few he‚Äôs been working on), and finally, acts as our digital Sherpa for Project Everest, an assault on software integrity and confidentiality that aims to build and deploy a verified HTTPS stack.

","hash":"a0fadc6f4c3afd10d37a3dfa744aa8d0","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"33183eac-abff-4598-b639-f588adba9beb","title":"057 (rerun) - Making intelligence intelligible with Dr. Rich Caruana","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_057_caruana_rerun.mp3","published":"2019-01-02T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

The episode first aired in May, 2018.
In the world of machine learning, there‚Äôs been a notable trade-off between accuracy and intelligibility. Either the models are accurate but difficult to make sense of, or easy to understand but prone to error. That‚Äôs why Dr. Rich Caruana, Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research, has spent a good part of his career working to make the simple more accurate and the accurate more intelligible.

Today, Dr. Caruana talks about how the rise of deep neural networks has made understanding machine predictions more difficult for humans, and discusses an interesting class of smaller, more interpretable models that may help to make the black box nature of machine learning more transparent.

","hash":"8e5e207962897eca556651f5bc8f8cec","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"d8f3937e-a055-4b16-b548-5ab4f5dd4ec1","title":"056 (rerun) - Functional Programming Languages and the Pursuit of Laziness with Dr. Simon Peyton Jones","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_056_peytonjones_rerun.mp3","published":"2018-12-26T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in January, 2018.
When we look at a skyscraper or a suspension bridge, a simple search engine box on a screen looks tiny by comparison. But Dr. Simon Peyton Jones would like to remind us that computer programs, with hundreds of millions of lines of code, are actually among the largest structures human beings have ever built. A principle researcher at the Microsoft Research Lab in Cambridge, England, co-developer of the programming language Haskell, and a Fellow of Britain‚Äôs Royal Society, Simon Peyton Jones has dedicated his life to this very particular kind of construction work.

\n

Today, Dr. Peyton Jones shares his passion for functional programming research, reveals how a desire to help other researchers write and present better turned him into an unlikely YouTube star, and explains why, at least in the world of programming languages, purity is embarrassing, laziness is cool, and success should be avoided at all costs.

","hash":"2c89808f03e03e474381c426dc29b7e6","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"053823ed-07e2-46dd-b2e5-0d45c473bfa2","title":"055 (rerun) - Building Literate Machines with Dr. Adam Trischler","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_055_trischler_rerun.mp3","published":"2018-12-19T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in March, 2018.
Learning to read, think and communicate effectively is part of the curriculum for every young student. But Dr. Adam Trischler, Research Manager and leader of the Machine Comprehension team at Microsoft Research Montreal, would like to make it part of the curriculum for your computer as well. And he‚Äôs working on that, using methods from machine learning, deep neural networks, and other branches of AI to close the communication gap between humans and computers.

Today, Dr. Trischler talks about his dream of making literate machines, his efforts to design meta-learning algorithms that can actually learn to learn, the importance of what he calls ‚Äúfew-shot learning‚Äù in that meta-learning process, and how, through a process of one-to-many mapping in machine learning, our computers not may not only be answering our questions, but asking them as well.

","hash":"d9872c02a29c674488296dfa4fbfe090","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"f915db01-d3ac-4836-88f2-3f370fd4eb8b","title":"054 - Soundscaping the world with Amos Miller","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_054_miller.mp3","published":"2018-12-12T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Amos Miller is a product strategist on the Microsoft Research NeXT Enable team, and he‚Äôs played a pivotal role in bringing some of MSR‚Äôs most innovative research to users with disabilities. He also happens to be blind, so he can appreciate, perhaps in ways others can‚Äôt, the value of the technologies he works on, like Soundscape, an app which enhances mobility independence through audio and sound.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Amos Miller answers burning questions like how do you make a microwave accessible, what‚Äôs the cocktail party effect, and how do you hear a landmark? He also talks about how researchers are exploring the untapped potential of 3D audio in virtual and augmented reality applications, and explains how, in the end, his work is not so much about making technology more accessible, but using technology to make life more accessible.

","hash":"97633d99e71a21fadf3f9e221237858f","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"43f81087-7bbf-48e1-b0a3-cf43ac7f5965","title":"053 - Chasing convex bodies and other random topics with Dr. Sebastien Bubeck","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_053_bubeck.mp3","published":"2018-12-05T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. Sebastien Bubeck is a mathematician and a senior researcher in the Machine Learning and Optimization group at Microsoft Research. He‚Äôs also a self-proclaimed ‚Äúbandit‚Äù who claims that, despite all the buzz around AI, it‚Äôs still a science in its infancy. That‚Äôs why he‚Äôs devoted his career to advancing the mathematical foundations behind the machine learning algorithms behind AI.

\n

Today, Dr. Bubeck explains the difficulty of the multi-armed bandit problem in the context of a parameter- and data-rich online world. He also discusses a host of topics from randomness and convex optimization to metrical task systems and log n competitiveness to the surprising connection between Gaussian kernels and what he calls some of the most beautiful objects in mathematics.

","hash":"34a1f0511cea41e3fce54c9ff135f215","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"93e5a5cf-1339-4647-88b1-3e0fa7fad44a","title":"052 - Machine learning and the learning machine with Dr. Christopher Bishop","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_052_bishop.mp3","published":"2018-11-28T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. Christopher Bishop is quite a fellow. Literally. Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering. Fellow of Darwin College in Cambridge, England. Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. Fellow of The Royal Society. Microsoft Technical Fellow. And one of the nicest fellows you‚Äôre likely to meet! He‚Äôs also Director of the Microsoft Research lab in Cambridge, where he oversees a world-class portfolio of research and development endeavors in machine learning and AI.

\n

Today, Dr. Bishop talks about the past, present and future of AI research, explains the No Free Lunch Theorem, talks about the modern view of machine learning (or how he learned to stop worrying and love uncertainty), and tells how the real excitement in the next few years will be the growth in our ability to create new technologies not by programming machines but by teaching them to learn.

","hash":"372a64725774d76f24ce214ed7e2bc06","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"bd110ad5-441d-4884-a771-f8d1a188818c","title":"051 (rerun) - When Psychology Meets Technology with Dr. Daniel McDuff","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_051_mcduff_rerun.mp3","published":"2018-11-21T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in March (2018)
One of the most intriguing areas of machine learning research is affective computing, where scientists are working to bridge the gap between human emotions and computers. It is here, at the intersection of psychology and computer science, that we find Dr. Daniel McDuff, who has been designing systems, from hardware to algorithms, that can sense human behavior and respond to human emotions.

\n

Today, Dr. McDuff talks about why we need computers to understand us, outlines the pros and cons of designing emotionally sentient agents, explains the technology behind CardioLens, a pair of augmented reality glasses that can take your heartrate by looking at your face, and addresses the challenges of maintaining trust and privacy when we‚Äôre surrounded by devices that want to know not just what we‚Äôre doing, but how we‚Äôre feeling.

\n

¬†

","hash":"35f62249ebaa4655d306a4ece3580163","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"d557f560-83bd-42c5-9579-b723e33a7276","title":"050 - Hearing in 3D with Dr. Ivan Tashev","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_050_tashev.mp3","published":"2018-11-14T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

After decades of research in processing audio signals, we‚Äôve reached the point of so-called performance saturation. But recent advances in machine learning and signal processing algorithms have paved the way for a revolution in speech recognition technology and audio signal processing. Dr. Ivan Tashev, a Partner Software Architect in the Audio and Acoustics Group at Microsoft Research, is no small part of the revolution, having both published papers and shipped products at the forefront of the science of sound.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Tashev gives us an overview of the quest for better sound processing and speech enhancement, tells us about the latest innovations in 3D audio, and explains why the research behind audio processing technology is, thanks to variations in human perception, equal parts science, art and craft.

","hash":"9d3e7e1120d8aaafa33644885ea9b450","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"8ac9ddaa-1554-4971-a546-19b17e90e9c2","title":"049 - Celebrating 20 Years of MSR in Asia with Dr. Hsiao-Wuen Hon","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_049_hon.mp3","published":"2018-11-07T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

In 1998, Microsoft Research opened a small lab in Beijing to expand its research efforts and draw on the immense high-tech talent pool in China. No one expected that only twenty years later, MSR Asia would become the dynamic organization it is today, with innovative research contributing to nearly every part of Microsoft‚Äôs business. Dr. Hsiao-Wuen Hon has watched it grow from the beginning and this year, celebrates the lab‚Äôs 20th anniversary as Managing Director, Corporate Vice President and Chairman of Microsoft‚Äôs Asia-Pacific R&D Group.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Hon gives us a brief history of MSR Asia, from its humble beginnings to its significant role in the AI boom today, talks about MSR Asia‚Äôs unique talent pipeline, shares his vision for the complementary roles of machine intelligence and human wisdom, and explains why, he believes, the more progress we make in AI, the better we understand ourselves.

","hash":"9a35bd8eb05c64ea492515623585dd9f","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"7305028e-3cd1-4d0c-8e2f-81252cab6ded","title":"048 - Storing Digital Data in Synthetic DNA with Dr. Karin Strauss","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_048_strauss.mp3","published":"2018-10-31T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

As traditional semiconductor technologies for computer storage scale down, everyone is looking for alternative solutions to the growing gap between the amount of data we‚Äôre capable of producing and the amount of data we‚Äôre capable of storing. While some have focused on hardware accelerators for machine learning, and others are investigating new memory technologies, Dr. Karin Strauss, a Senior Researcher at Microsoft Research in Redmond, has been exploring the role of biotechnology in IT via an end-to-end system that stores digital data in DNA.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Strauss talks about life at the intersection of computer science and biology which, for many, is more like the intersection of science fiction and science, and explains how the unique properties of DNA could eventually enable us to store really big data in really small places for a really long time.

","hash":"ce8c667d8799a5f8dcf50d41571ae5f3","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"8858b292-62cf-4957-b055-b5d06c1a6bd1","title":"046 - Designing the Future With the Help of the Past with Bill Buxton","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_046_Buxton.mp3","published":"2018-10-17T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

The ancient Chinese philosopher Confucius famously exhorted his pupils to study the past if they would divine the future. In 2018, we get the same advice from a decidedly more modern, but equally philosophical Bill Buxton, Principal Researcher in the HCI group at Microsoft Research. In addition to his pioneering work in computer science and design, Bill Buxton has spent the past several decades amassing a collection of more than a thousand artifacts that chronicle the history of human computer interaction for the very purpose of informing the future of human computer interaction.

\n

Today, in a wide-ranging interview, Bill Buxton explains why Marcel Proust and TS Eliot can be instructive for computer scientists, why the long nose of innovation is essential to success in technology design, why problem-setting is more important than problem-solving, and why we must remember, as we design our technologies, that every technological decision we make is an ethical decision as well.

","hash":"6e29db1f98e0716a1db0b839a0c334ae","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0617cf94-dda0-4331-ae68-f129b7ac561f","title":"045 - Leading Labs with Dr. Jennifer Chayes","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_045_chayes.mp3","published":"2018-10-10T14:00:00Z","show_notes":"

2018 marks the 10th anniversary of Microsoft Research New England in Cambridge, Massachusetts, so it‚Äôs the perfect time to talk with someone who was there from the lab‚Äôs beginning: Technical Fellow, Managing Director and Co-founder, Dr. Jennifer Chayes. But not only does Dr. Chayes run the New England lab of MSR, she also directs two other highly renowned, interdisciplinary research labs in New York City and Montreal, Quebec. Add to that a full slate of personal research projects and service on numerous boards, committees and foundations, and you‚Äôve got one of the busiest and most influential women in high tech.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Chayes shares her passion for the value of undirected inquiry, talks about her unlikely journey from rebel to researcher, and explains how she believes her research philosophy ‚Äì more botanist than boss ‚Äì prepares the fertile ground necessary for important, innovative and impactful research.

","hash":"8feb9e06fb9f4f2e2227dd2defcf65b9","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"6bf8401b-ea8f-47a1-a0aa-3d8941b01d3f","title":"044 - The Future is Fusion with Asta Roseway","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_044_Roseway.mp3","published":"2018-10-03T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Asta Roseway has a formal title. It‚Äôs Principal Research Designer in the HCI group at Microsoft Research. But she‚Äôs also been described as a conductor, an alchemist, a millennial in a Gen-Xer‚Äôs body and, in her own words, a fusionist. What‚Äôs a fusionist, you might ask? Well, you‚Äôre about to find out.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Asta gives an inside look at one of the most unconventional labs at Microsoft Research. Located at the intersection of science, technology and art, it‚Äôs a lab that insists that technology, like art, should push boundaries, tell stories and feed our souls. Get ready for the unexpected because when Asta asks ‚Äúwhat if?‚Äù you‚Äôre likely to find yourself immersed in a world of responsive clothing, smart tattoos, talking plants and even environmentally sensitive‚Ä¶ makeup!

","hash":"60aa9add76f0d56351f6c7028089d925","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"2db84229-bd83-43a2-9c4d-a5a699a4bdaf","title":"043 - All About Automated Machine Learning with Dr. Nicolo Fusi","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_043_fusi.mp3","published":"2018-09-26T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

You may have heard the phrase, necessity is the mother of invention, but for Dr. Nicolo Fusi, a researcher at the Microsoft Research lab in Cambridge, MA, the mother of his invention wasn‚Äôt so much necessity as it was boredom: the special machine learning boredom of manually fine-tuning models and hyper-parameters that can eat up tons of human and computational resources, but bring no guarantee of a good result. His solution? Automate machine learning with a meta-model that figures out what other models are doing, and then predicts how they‚Äôll work on a given dataset.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Fusi gives us an inside look at Automated Machine Learning ‚Äì Microsoft‚Äôs version of the industry‚Äôs AutoML technology ‚Äì and shares the story of how an idea he had while working on a gene editing problem with CRISPR/Cas9 turned into a bit of a machine learning side quest and, ultimately, a surprisingly useful instantiation of Automated Machine Learning - now a feature of Azure Machine Learning - that reduces dependence on intuition and takes some of the tedium out of data science at the same time.

","hash":"41e16e3f17aabe25bf19de3b2bcdcd94","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"19ecdfab-ef22-4003-bea6-6fc4e452f9c3","title":"042 - Internships Ahoy! with Kirsten Bray, Wei Dai and Sara Beery","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_042_interns.mp3","published":"2018-09-19T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

At the heart of any vibrant research community, you‚Äôll find a diverse range of scientists. You‚Äôre also likely to find a robust internship program, like the one at Microsoft Research. This summer, MSR welcomed another stellar group of interns who had the opportunity to learn, collaborate, and network with colleagues and mentors who will impact their lives for years to come.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, you‚Äôll hear the stories of three of these interns, each of whom came to Microsoft Research from a different field, with a different story and a different perspective, but all of whom share MSR‚Äôs passion for finding innovative solutions to the world‚Äôs toughest challenges.

","hash":"dd1a8b4400a2c3dba64af71015c80bfc","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"41f9d2b5-25f2-4cc7-8baf-5d15f9993559","title":"041 - Playing to the Crowd and Other Social Media Mandates with Dr. Nancy Baym","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_041_Baym.mp3","published":"2018-09-12T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. Nancy Baym is a communication scholar, a Principal Researcher in MSR‚Äôs Cambridge, Massachusetts, lab, and something of a cyberculture maven. She‚Äôs spent nearly three decades studying how people use communication technologies in their everyday relationships and written several books on the subject. The big take away? Communication technologies may have changed drastically over the years, but human communication itself? Not so much.

\n

Today, Dr. Baym shares her insights on a host of topics ranging from the arduous maintenance requirements of social media, to the dialectic tension between connection and privacy, to the funhouse mirror nature of emerging technologies. She also talks about her new book, Playing to the Crowd: Musicians, Audiences and the Intimate Work of Connection, which explores how the internet transformed ‚Äì for better and worse ‚Äì the relationship between artists and their fans.

","hash":"e8204fb8be3a57b99e82b00173b207da","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"98774b4f-3799-4348-aae9-8a78fb2b1bed","title":"040 - Putting the Cloud Under the Sea with Ben Cutler","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_040_Cutler.mp3","published":"2018-09-05T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Datacenters have a hard time keeping their cool. Literally. And with more and more datacenters coming online all over the world, calls for innovative solutions to ‚Äúcool the cloud‚Äù are getting loud. So, Ben Cutler and the Special Projects team at Microsoft Research decided to try to beat the heat by using one of the best natural venues for cooling off on the planet: the ocean. That led to Project Natick, Microsoft‚Äôs prototype plan to deploy a new class of eco-friendly datacenters, under water, at scale, anywhere in the world, from decision to power-on, in 90 days. Because, presumably for Special Projects, go big or go home.

\n

In today‚Äôs podcast we find out a bit about what else the Special Projects team is up to, and then we hear all about Project Natick and how Ben and his team conceived of, and delivered on, a novel idea to deal with the increasing challenges of keeping datacenters cool, safe, green, and, now, dry as well!

","hash":"b384616bd1c53f8bd149bc3be0a584c3","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"b0eb5578-cbc3-4233-bf87-c7d3974f9c3d","title":"039 - Malmo, Minecraft and Machine Learning with Dr. Katja Hofmann","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_hofmann_036.mp3","published":"2018-08-29T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

The wildly popular video game, Minecraft, might appear to be an unlikely candidate for machine learning research, but to Dr. Katja Hofmann, the research lead of Project Malmo in the Machine Intelligence and Perception Group at Microsoft Research in Cambridge, England, it‚Äôs the perfect environment for teaching AI agents, via reinforcement learning, to act intelligently ‚Äì and cooperatively ‚Äì in the open world.

\n

Today, Dr. Hofmann talks about her vision of a future where machines learn to collaborate with people and empower them to help solve complex, real-world problems. She also shares the story of how her early years in East Germany, behind the Iron Curtain, shaped her both personally and professionally, and ultimately facilitated a creative, exploratory mindset about computing that informs her work to this day.

","hash":"eeef92083bddbebc31e8a9c892f26df9","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"eaeec94e-f12c-4226-97f0-8a1a1c7c2701","title":"038 - Cryptography for the Post-Quantum World with Dr. Brian LaMacchia","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_038_LaMacchia.mp3","published":"2018-08-22T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

You know those people who work behind the scenes to make sure nothing bad happens to you, and if they‚Äôre really good, you never know who they are because nothing bad happens to you? Well, meet one of those people. Dr. Brian LaMacchia is a Distinguished Engineer and he heads up the Security and Cryptography Group at Microsoft Research. It‚Äôs his job to make sure ‚Äì using up-to-the-minute math ‚Äì that you‚Äôre safe and secure online, both now, and in the post-quantum world to come.

\n

Today, Dr. LaMacchia gives us an inside look at the world of cryptography and the number theory behind it, explains what happens when good algorithms go bad, and tells us why, even though cryptographically relevant quantum computers are still decades away, we need to start developing quantum-resistant algorithms right now.

","hash":"300862f3a1778e1a8ca97f1cc3a4c691","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"e7805d72-232b-473f-bb9a-e9aae69388b2","title":"037 - A Brief History of Networking (and a Bit About the Future Too) with Dr. Victor Bahl","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_037_bahl.mp3","published":"2018-08-15T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If your idea of a great job includes pursuing untethered research, shepherding brilliant researchers and helping shape the long-term strategy of one of the largest tech companies in the world‚Ä¶ oh, and also publishing prolifically, authoring patents, winning awards and speaking around the world‚Ä¶ you are in good company. ","hash":"24ccc6cd9ec59c0a8bb1ada4a38e3f4e","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ac63bf25-0da9-4a1f-934b-0e607c3b39c4","title":"036 - A Conversation with Microsoft CTO Kevin Scott","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_scott_036.mp3","published":"2018-08-08T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Kevin Scott has embraced many roles over the course of his illustrious career in technology: software developer, engineering executive, researcher, angel investor, philanthropist, and now, Chief Technology Officer of Microsoft. ","hash":"47bcfb3181e2fc7bf642e1cde0b854e2","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"87957757-e4ef-44c2-a40b-fb9e6f35e200","title":"035 - Research You Can (Really) Use with Dr. Lenin Ravindranath Sivalingam","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_sivalingam_035.mp3","published":"2018-08-01T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. Lenin Ravindranath Sivalingam is a researcher by trade, but by nature, he‚Äôs an entrepreneur, and a hacker with a heart of gold. Today, Dr. Ravindranath Sivalingam tells us why he is so passionate about what he does, explains how internships can literally change your life, and shares the story of how a hackathon idea turned into a prize-winning project‚Ä¶ and then became the backbone of a powerhouse tool for gamers and their fans.

","hash":"4222cb8b88fc7eefa3bd077d94a4466a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"c5506962-9059-477b-ba4e-7da0e385b10c","title":"034 (rerun) - The future is quantum with Dr. Krysta Svore","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_horvitz_033_RERUN.mp3","published":"2018-07-25T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

First aired on January 17, 2018. If someone mentions quantum computing, and you find yourself outwardly nodding your head, but secretly shaking it, you‚Äôre in good company: some of the world‚Äôs smartest people admit they don‚Äôt really understand it either. Fortunately, some of the world‚Äôs other smartest people, like Dr. Krysta Svore, Principal Research Manager of the Microsoft Quantum ‚Äì or QuArC ‚Äì group at Microsoft Research in Redmond, actually DO understand quantum computing, and are working hard to make it a reality.

Today, Dr. Svore shares her passion for quantum algorithms and their potential to solve some of the world‚Äôs biggest problems, explains why Microsoft‚Äôs topological quantum bit ‚Äì or qubit ‚Äì is a game changer for quantum computing, and assures us that, although qubits live in dilution refrigerators at temperatures near absolute zero, quantum researchers can still sit in the comfort of their offices and work with the computer programmer‚Äôs equivalent of Schroedinger‚Äôs Cat.

","hash":"d7d02bff9576930c26be075c939e7616","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"6bd4809d-ba10-450c-abc4-0e0e06770249","title":"032 (rerun) - How Programming Languages Quietly Run the World with Dr. Ben Zorn","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_zorn_RERUN.mp3","published":"2018-07-11T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in January (2018).
In an era of AI breakthroughs and other exciting advances in computer science, Dr. Ben Zorn would like to remind us that behind every great technical revolution is‚Ä¶ a programming language. As a Principal Researcher and the Co-director of RiSE ‚Äì or Research in Software Engineering ‚Äì group at Microsoft Research, Dr. Zorn has dedicated his life to making sure the software that now touches nearly everything in our lives is easy, accurate, reliable and secure. Today, Dr. Zorn tells us some great stories about bugs and whales, warns us against the dumb side of ‚Äúsmart‚Äù objects, shares about his group‚Äôs attempt to scale the Everest of software security, and makes a great case that the most important programming language in the world today is‚Ä¶ the spreadsheet.

","hash":"fd773bc189c8f38d4372b62cd831bd6d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"e8b75408-4cc9-4942-93d7-e4673774b75f","title":"031 (rerun) - AI for the Developing World with Dr. Ranveer Chandra","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_chandra_RERUN.mp3","published":"2018-07-04T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in April (2018).
When we think about artificial intelligence and the ‚Äúworld of the future,‚Äù our vision is usually more Jetsons than Green Acres. But for Dr. Ranveer Chandra, a Principal Researcher in the Systems and Networking group at Microsoft Research, rural farms are the perfect place to realize the benefits of AI through what he calls precision agriculture, or data-driven farming.

Today, in a wide-ranging interview, Dr. Chandra talks about how his research may eventually make your wi-fi signal stronger and your battery life longer, but also shares the story of how spending childhood summers with his grandparents in rural India inspired a line of research that could change the face of farming and help meet the food and nutrition needs of a growing global population.

","hash":"3a9d9657ed3657bacc08910fa99e39f4","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"36693ecb-a537-467c-a269-e82588336f33","title":"030 - Examining the Social Impacts of Artificial Intelligence with Dr. Fernando Diaz","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_diaz_030.mp3","published":"2018-06-27T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Developing complex artificial intelligence systems in a lab is a challenging task, but what happens when they go into production and interact with real humans? That‚Äôs what researchers like Dr. Fernando Diaz, a Principal Research Manager at Microsoft Research Montreal, want to know. He and his colleagues are trying to understand ‚Äì and address ‚Äì the social implications of these systems as they enter the open world.

\n

Today, Dr. Diaz shares his insights on the kinds of questions we need to be asking about artificial intelligence and its impact on society. He also talks about how algorithms can affect your taste in music, and why now, more than ever, computer science education needs to teach ethics along with algorithms.

","hash":"9bd803a1e8aa1f4fca8384363c40268a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0d9b17cb-ade9-49f1-8dbc-a3cc6150dd38","title":"029 (rerun) - Notes from the Productivity Revolution with Dr. Jaime Teevan","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_teevan_RR_029.mp3","published":"2018-06-21T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in November (2017). Dr. Jaime Teevan has a lot to say about productivity in a fragmented culture, and some solutions that seem promising, if somewhat counter-intuitive. Dr. Teevan is a Microsoft researcher, University of Washington Affiliate Professor, and the mother of four young boys. Today she talks about what she calls the productivity revolution, and explains how her research in micro-productivity ‚Äì making use of short fragments of time to help us accomplish larger tasks -¬† could help us be more productive, and experience a better quality of life at the same time.

","hash":"47ce8e6a5d0fe36e67ec257e52f6ea5a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"682731ef-4694-46df-86ae-f560d6c51bf9","title":"028 - Teaching Computers to See with Dr. Gang Hua","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_hua_028.mp3","published":"2018-06-13T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

In technical terms, computer vision researchers ‚Äúbuild algorithms and systems to automatically analyze imagery and extract knowledge from the visual world.‚Äù In layman‚Äôs terms, they build machines that can see. And that‚Äôs exactly what Principal Researcher and Research Manager, Dr. Gang Hua, and Computer Vision Technology team, are doing. Because being able to see is really important for things like the personal robots, self-driving cars, and autonomous drones we‚Äôre seeing more and more in our daily lives.

\n

Today, Dr. Hua talks about how the latest advances in AI and machine learning are making big improvements on image recognition, video understanding and even the arts. He also explains the distributed ensemble approach to active learning, where humans and machines work together in the lab to get computer vision systems ready to see and interpret the open world.

","hash":"2c9a75f5c1b46ad7bdf959c1ff867e2e","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"d65d946f-70e5-4039-9e37-c1ec6cd2a91b","title":"027 - The Democratization of Data Science with Dr. Chris White","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_white_027.mp3","published":"2018-06-06T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When we think of medals, we usually picture them over the pocket of a military hero, not over the pocket protector of a computer scientist. That may be because not many academics end up working with the Department of Defense. But Dr. Chris White, now a Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research, has, and he‚Äôs received several awards for his efforts in fighting terrorism and crime with big data, statistics and machine learning.

\n

Today, Dr. White talks about his ‚Äúproblem-first‚Äù approach to research, explains the vital importance of making data understandable for everyone, and shares the story of how a one-week detour from academia turned into an extended tour in Afghanistan, a stint at DARPA, and, eventually, a career at Microsoft Research.

","hash":"a0c3ae35d5f5a2747d4cfd0e9c24e8fa","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"94681246-24d6-4686-ba70-3cfb21e8aab5","title":"026 - Making Intelligence Intelligible with Dr. Rich Caruana","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_caruana_026.mp3","published":"2018-05-30T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

In the world of machine learning, there‚Äôs been a notable trade-off between accuracy and intelligibility. Either the models are accurate but difficult to make sense of, or easy to understand but prone to error. That‚Äôs why Dr. Rich Caruana, Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research, has spent a good part of his career working to make the simple more accurate and the accurate more intelligible.

\n

Today, Dr. Caruana talks about how the rise of deep neural networks has made understanding machine predictions more difficult for humans, and discusses an interesting class of smaller, more interpretable models that may help to make the black box nature of machine learning more transparent.

","hash":"d32f5bbd915b1ea5cacd4723bf3f7b50","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"9db456ba-8804-43dd-9e11-da0e2053232f","title":"025 - Advancing Accessibility with Dr. Meredith Ringel Morris","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_ringelmorris_025.mp3","published":"2018-05-23T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

With 7 billion people on the planet, you might be surprised to learn that approximately a billion of those people experience some form of disability. Enter Principal Researcher and Research Manager, Dr. Merrie Ringel Morris, and the Ability Group at Microsoft Research. They‚Äôre working to remove accessibility barriers both to and through technology, empowering people with disabilities to better perform their daily tasks.

\n

Today, Dr. Morris gives us some fascinating insights into the world of ‚Äúability,‚Äù talks about how technology is augmenting not only sensory and motor abilities, but cognitive and social abilities as well, and shares how Microsoft, through its AI for Accessibility initiative, is committed to extending the capabilities and enhancing the quality of life for every person on the planet.

\n
