","hash":"87e03605c52d710506ba65120c90856e","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"2dc28b51-ac61-4566-8c1e-3e583b608b1c","title":"024 - Not Lost in Translation with Arul Menezes","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_menezes_024.mp3","published":"2018-05-16T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Humans are wired to communicate, but we don‚Äôt always understand each other. Especially when we don‚Äôt speak the same language. But Arul Menezes, the Partner Research Manager who heads MSR‚Äôs Machine Translation team, is working to remove language barriers to help people communicate better. And with the help of some innovative machine learning techniques, and the combined brainpower of machine translation, natural language and machine learning teams in Redmond and Beijing, it‚Äôs happening sooner than anyone expected.

\n

Today, Menezes talks about how the advent of deep learning has enabled exciting advances in machine translation, including applications for people with disabilities, and gives us an inside look at the recent ‚Äúhuman parity‚Äù milestone at Microsoft Research, where machines translated a news dataset from Chinese to English with the same accuracy and quality as a person.

","hash":"b16fb6b7cd5742581112897264eccddc","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"fec31104-6e7e-43a0-b627-2a896e0b1934","title":"023 - Clouds, Catapults and Life After the End of Moore‚Äôs Law with Dr. Doug Burger","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_burger_023.mp3","published":"2018-05-09T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Some of the world‚Äôs leading architects are people that you‚Äôve probably never heard of, and they‚Äôve designed and built some of the world‚Äôs most amazing structures that you‚Äôve probably never seen. Or at least you don‚Äôt think you have. One of these architects is Dr. Doug Burger, Distinguished Engineer at Microsoft Research NExT. And, if you use a computer, or store anything in the Cloud, you‚Äôre a beneficiary of the beautiful architecture that he, and people like him, work on every day.

\n

Today, in a fast-paced interview, Dr. Burger talks about how advances in AI and deep machine learning have placed new acceleration demands on current hardware and computer architecture, offers some observations about the demise of Moore‚Äôs Law, and shares his vision of what life might look like in a post-CPU, post-von-Neumann computing world.

","hash":"13ba020da81c447026f4e17468d6c5a9","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"c612cff9-0330-4b5c-a8f1-69100470ce2a","title":"022 - Machine Learning and the Incredible Flying Robot with Dr. Ashish Kapoor","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_kapoor_022.mp3","published":"2018-05-02T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Autonomous flying agents ‚Äì or flying robots ‚Äì may seem like the stuff of sci-fi to the average person, but to Dr. Ashish Kapoor, Principal Researcher and Research Manager of the Aerial Informatics and Robotics Group at Microsoft Research, they‚Äôre much closer to science than to fiction. And, having built ‚Äì and flight tested ‚Äì his own airplane, complete with state-of-the-art avionics designed to run AI and ML algorithms, he has the street cred ‚Äì or should we say flight cred ‚Äì to prove it.

\n

Today, Dr. Kapoor talks about how cutting-edge machine learning techniques are empowering a new generation of autonomous vehicles, and tells us all about AirSim, an innovative platform that‚Äôs helping bridge the simulator-to-reality gap, paving the way for safer, more robust real-world AI systems of all kinds

","hash":"828a30e5bd2bcee20d26e026b8971341","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0486e1e9-6cec-4c02-b416-8ea0afa7998d","title":"021 - AI, ML and the Reasoning Machine with Dr. Geoff Gordon","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_gordon_021.mp3","published":"2018-04-25T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Teaching computers to read, think and communicate like humans is a daunting task, but it‚Äôs one that Dr. Geoff Gordon embraces with enthusiasm and optimism. Moving from an academic role at Carnegie Mellon University, to a new role as Research Director of the Microsoft Research Lab in Montreal, Dr. Gordon embodies the current trend toward the partnership between academia and industry as we enter what many believe will be a new era of progress in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

\n

Today, Dr. Gordon gives us a brief history of AI, including his assessment of why we might see a break in the weather-pattern of AI winters, talks about how collaboration is essential to innovation in machine learning, shares his vision of the mindset it takes to tackle the biggest questions in AI, and reveals his life-long quest to make computers less‚Ä¶ well, less computer-like.

","hash":"a9199cb0f0f12b344faeceb66bff46a3","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"4f7e8355-151e-407e-b2b3-74a808fb1872","title":"020 - Getting Good VIBEs from Your Computer with Dr. Mary Czerwinski","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_czerwinski_020.mp3","published":"2018-04-18T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Emotions are fundamental to human interaction, but in a world where humans are increasingly interacting with AI systems, Dr. Mary Czerwinski, Principal Researcher and Research Manager of the Visualization and Interaction for Business and Entertainment group at Microsoft Research, believes emotions may be fundamental to our interactions with machines as well. And through her team‚Äôs work in affective computing, the quest to bring Artificial Emotional Intelligence ‚Äì or AEI ‚Äì to our computers may be closer than we think.

\n

Today, Dr. Czerwinski tells us how a cognitive psychologist found her way into the research division of the world‚Äôs largest software company, suggests that rather than trying to be productive 24/7, we should aim for Emotional Homeostasis instead, and tells us how, if we do it right, our machines could become a sort of ‚Äúemotional at-work DJ,‚Äù sensing and responding to our emotional states, and helping us to become happier and more productive at the same time.

","hash":"2f00d06eb2d78190683b9ed4ecc0dd8d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"3317ba71-54ab-41c8-b8d7-9e071d9ca21e","title":"019 - Tales from the Crypt(ography) Lab with Dr. Kristin Lauter","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_lauter_019.mp3","published":"2018-04-11T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

From ancient hieroglyphics to secret decoder rings to World War II Enigma code-makers and code-breakers, cryptography has always held a particular fascination for us. But few of us have the skills ‚Äì or can actually do the math ‚Äì to unlock the mysteries of encrypted data. Fortunately, Dr. Kristin Lauter, distinguished mathematician, founder of the Women in Numbers Network, and Principal Researcher and Research Manager for the Cryptography Group at Microsoft Research, can. And she is using her powers for good, not for evil!

\n

Today, Dr. Lauter tells us why she feels lucky¬† to do math for a living, explains the singular beauty of elliptic curves and the singular difficulty of supersingular isogeny graphs, talks about how homomorphic encryption ‚Äì part of the field of Private AI ‚Äì allows us to operate on, while still protecting, our most sensitive data, and shares her dream of one day, seeing a Grace Hopper-like conference to celebrate women in mathematics.

","hash":"43c5586bce35b426a1a8de3c93b3ddad","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"16bfad38-1de2-4080-885f-c4c167fcb8ff","title":"018 - AI for the Developing World with Dr. Ranveer Chandra","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_chandra_018.mp3","published":"2018-04-04T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When we think about artificial intelligence and the ‚Äúworld of the future,‚Äù our vision is usually more Jetsons than Green Acres. But for Dr. Ranveer Chandra, a Principal Researcher in the Systems and Networking group at Microsoft Research, rural farms are the perfect place to realize the benefits of AI through what he calls precision agriculture, or data-driven farming.

\n

Today, in a wide-ranging interview, Dr. Chandra talks about how his research may eventually make your Wi-Fi signal stronger and your battery life longer, but also shares the story of how spending childhood summers with his grandparents in rural India inspired a line of research that could change the face of farming and help meet the food and nutrition needs of a growing global population.

","hash":"328863edfb662525b338388e6723a745","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"82f72526-2bb6-4145-b05a-c2c11dd55c7c","title":"017 - When Psychology Meets Technology with Dr. Daniel McDuff","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_mcduff_017.mp3","published":"2018-03-28T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

One of the most intriguing areas of machine learning research is affective computing, where scientists are working to bridge the gap between human emotions and computers. It is here, at the intersection of psychology and computer science, that we find Dr. Daniel McDuff, who has been designing systems, from hardware to algorithms, that can sense human behavior and respond to human emotions.

\n

Today, Dr. McDuff talks about why we need computers to understand us, outlines the pros and cons of designing emotionally sentient agents, explains the technology behind CardioLens, a pair of augmented reality glasses that can take your heartrate by looking at your face, and addresses the challenges of maintaining trust and privacy when we‚Äôre surrounded by devices that want to know not just what we‚Äôre doing, but how we‚Äôre feeling.

","hash":"29c2456119d621516f174d99ef771e40","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"979b1bae-40b8-4b4a-918d-a7ecf0e02d26","title":"016 - Building Literate Machines with Dr. Adam Trischler","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_trischler_016.mp3","published":"2018-03-21T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Learning to read, think and communicate effectively is part of the curriculum for every young student. But Dr. Adam Trischler, Research Manager and leader of the Machine Comprehension team at Microsoft Research Montreal, would like to make it part of the curriculum for your computer as well. And he‚Äôs working on that, using methods from machine learning, deep neural networks, and other branches of AI to close the communication gap between humans and computers.

\n

Today, Dr. Trischler talks about his dream of making literate machines, his efforts to design meta-learning algorithms that can actually learn to learn, the importance of what he calls ‚Äúfew-shot learning‚Äù in that meta-learning process, and how, through a process of one-to-many mapping in machine learning, our computers not may not only be answering our questions, but asking them as well.

\n

¬†

","hash":"65d219efa3e6a82129ae6e20212f133d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"cafe8905-7877-405d-9dc8-92fd82daf7d1","title":"015 - Brokering Peace Talks in the Networking and Storage Arms Race with Dr. Anirudh Badam","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_badam_015.mp3","published":"2018-03-07T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

There‚Äôs a big gap between memory and storage, and Dr. Anirudh Badam, of the Systems Research Group at Microsoft Research, wants to close it. With projects like Navamem, which explores how systems can get faster and better by adopting new memory technologies, and HashCache, which brings with it the promise of storage for the next billion, he just might do it.

\n

Today, Dr. Badam discusses the historic trade-offs between volatile and non-volatile memory, shares how software-defined batteries are changing the power-supply landscape, talks about how his research is aiming for the trifecta of speed, cost and capacity in new memory technologies, and reminds us, once again, how one good high school physics teacher can inspire the next generation of scientific discovery.

\n

","hash":"0adf0df17b2b9ce732f85f82537a2974","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"dad48f83-ac3c-4524-8ae6-13a0cf1b483b","title":"014 - Keeping an Eye on AI with Dr. Kate Crawford","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_crawford_014.mp3","published":"2018-02-28T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

Artificial intelligence has captured our imagination and made many things we would have thought impossible only a few years ago seem commonplace today. But AI has also raised some challenging issues for society writ large. Enter Dr. Kate Crawford, a principal researcher at the New York City lab of Microsoft Research. Dr. Crawford, along with an illustrious group of colleagues in computer science, engineering, social science, business and law, has dedicated her research to addressing the social implications of AI, including big topics like bias, labor and automation, rights and liberties, and ethics and governance.

\n


Today, Dr. Crawford talks about both the promises and the problems of AI; why‚Äî when it comes to data ‚Äì bigger isn‚Äôt necessarily better; and how ‚Äì even in an era of increasingly complex technological advances ‚Äì we can adopt AI design principles that empower people to shape their technical tools in ways they‚Äôd like to use them most.

\n

","hash":"c839ab6a1653153bab93033634dd8203","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"134d0147-753d-4ae5-bfd8-84c633db8271","title":"013 - Machine Learning and the InnerEye for Cancer Treatment with Dr. Antonio Criminisi","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_criminisi_013.mp3","published":"2018-02-21T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

With all the sensational headlines about artificial intelligence, it‚Äôs reassuring to know that some of the world‚Äôs most brilliant minds are developing AI systems for entirely practical reasons. One of those minds belongs to Dr. Antonio Criminisi, a Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research in Cambridge, England. And one of those reasons is to help medical professionals provide better healthcare to their patients.

Today, Dr. Criminisi talks about Project InnerEye, an innovative machine learning tool that helps radiologists identify and analyze 3-D images of cancerous tumors. He also gives us some insight into his work on deep neural decision forests and tells us how gaming algorithms made their way into medical technology, moving from gamer to patient, and turning outside-in imaging‚Ä¶ inside-out.

\n

¬†

\n

","hash":"c2ac75ba71f8194a39db78163db6c2c4","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ca866cc5-2579-4ccd-b3f9-695c3b926d44","title":"012 - Code in the Classroom with Dr. Peli de Halleux","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_dehalleux_012.mp3","published":"2018-02-15T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

If you‚Äôve ever wondered if you could find the perfect combination of computer scientist‚Ä¶ and Macgyver, look no further than Dr. Peli de Halleux, principal Research Software Design Engineer at Microsoft Research. A key member of the MSR RiSE team, Peli is part of the MakeCode initiative that brings physical computing to classrooms around the country and around the world. Today, Peli talks about the Maker Movement in K-12 education, the hard work that goes on behind the scenes to deliver a ‚Äúseamless‚Äù user experience for both kids and teachers, and how to get children excited about coding through hands on experience in early computer science education.

\n

","hash":"f7a3da62dd68de4234bdefbd24b6ee28","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"cb04d894-2b7f-49a7-81a7-ed78ba177503","title":"011 - Getting LinkedIn to Data Science with Dr. Igor Perisic","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_perisic_011.mp3","published":"2018-02-07T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Big data is a big deal, and if you follow the popular technical press, you‚Äôll have heard all the metaphors: data is the new oil, the new bacon, the new currency, the new electricity. It‚Äôs even been called the new black. While data may not actually be any of these things, we can say this: in today‚Äôs networked world, data is increasingly valuable and it is essential to research, both basic and applied.

\n

Today, we welcome a special guest to the podcast. Dr. Igor Perisic is the Vice President of Engineering and Chief Data Officer at LinkedIn, the social network for business and employment. Today, Dr. Perisic talks about the key attributes of a data scientist, how AI and machine learning are helping personalize member experiences, why we should all be big open source fans, and how LinkedIn is partnering with other researchers through their innovative Economic Graph program to create economic opportunity for every member of the global workforce.

\n

All this and much more on this episode of the Microsoft Research Podcast.

","hash":"2dcd995e051e296e3b113a76cd408a19","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"257f4e2c-fac2-4228-96b3-6f8a80817e05","title":"010 - Neural Program Synthesis and the Quest to Democratize Programming with Dr. Rishabh Singh","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_Singh_010.mp3","published":"2018-01-31T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Every day, computers take on more and more of our daily tasks. Fill in a few cells on your spreadsheet? It‚Äôll fill in the rest. Ask your car for directions? It‚Äôll get you there. Anymore, we can program computers to do almost anything. But what about programming computers to‚Ä¶ program computers? That‚Äôs a task that Dr. Rishabh Singh, and the team in the Cognition group at Microsoft Research, are tackling with Neural Program Synthesis, also known as artificial programming.

\n


Today, Dr. Singh explains how deep neural networks are already training computers to do things like take classes and grade assignments, shares how programmers can perform complicated, high-level debugging through the delightfully named process of neural fuzzing, and lays out his vision to democratize computer programming in the brave new world of Software 2.0.

\n

","hash":"777b7e2a7c0eb7a6a49e81a12ce46e7b","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ea4f5b53-7fa3-4e6a-a164-37eb9683e9c4","title":"009 - Life at the Intersection of AI and Society with Dr. Ece Kamar","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_kamar_009.mp3","published":"2018-01-24T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

As the reality of artificial intelligence continues to capture our imagination, and critical AI systems enter our world at a rapid pace, Dr. Ece Kamar, a senior researcher in the Adaptive Systems and Interaction Group at Microsoft Research, is working to help us understand AI‚Äôs far-reaching implications, both as we use it, and as we build it.

\n


Today, Dr. Kamar talks about the complementarity between humans and machines, debunks some common misperceptions about AI, reveals how we can overcome bias and blind spots by putting humans in the AI loop, and argues convincingly that, despite everything machines can do (and they can do a lot), humans are still ‚Äúthe real deal.‚Äù

\n

","hash":"24f78affe4c76374135bba6107f65fed","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"cf92e438-38f1-4947-9522-16c47e4db9f9","title":"008 - The Future is Quantum with Dr. Krysta Svore","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_ksvore_008.mp3","published":"2018-01-17T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

If someone mentions quantum computing, and you find yourself outwardly nodding your head, but secretly shaking it, you‚Äôre in good company: some of the world‚Äôs smartest people admit they don‚Äôt really understand it either. Fortunately, some of the world‚Äôs other smartest people, like Dr. Krysta Svore, Principal Research Manager of the Microsoft Quantum ‚Äì or QuArC - group at Microsoft Research in Redmond, actually DO understand quantum computing, and are working hard to make it a reality.

\n


Today, Dr. Svore shares her passion for quantum algorithms and their potential to solve some of the world‚Äôs biggest problems, explains why Microsoft‚Äôs topological quantum bit ‚Äì or qubit ‚Äì is a game changer for quantum computing, and assures us that, although qubits live in dilution refrigerators at temperatures near absolute zero, quantum researchers can still sit in the comfort of their offices and work with the computer programmer‚Äôs equivalent of Schroedinger‚Äôs Cat.

\n

","hash":"46bf8dc1d85346503674120cdb2e2163","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"4b3f5fd9-647c-4d70-a6b4-8338a7406967","title":"007 - Functional Programming Languages and the Pursuit of Laziness with Dr. Simon Peyton Jones","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_peytonjones_007.mp3","published":"2018-01-10T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

When we look at a skyscraper or a suspension bridge, a simple search engine box on a screen looks tiny by comparison. But Dr. Simon Peyton Jones would like to remind us that computer programs, with hundreds of millions of lines of code, are actually among the largest structures human beings have ever built. A principle researcher at the Microsoft Research Lab in Cambridge, England, co-developer of the programming language Haskell, and a Fellow of Britain‚Äôs Royal Society, Simon Peyton Jones has dedicated his life to this very particular kind of construction work.

\n

¬†

\n

¬†

\n

¬†

\n

Today, Dr. Peyton Jones shares his passion for functional programming research, reveals how a desire to help other researchers write and present better turned him into an unlikely YouTube star, and explains why, at least in the world of programming languages, purity is embarrassing, laziness is cool, and success should be avoided at all costs.

\n

","hash":"d29103e4c9be1f641f18d974b5db4b44","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"c32b8f17-a2dc-4210-9ef1-8a8aa90d5bc8","title":"006 - How Programming Languages Quietly Run the World with Dr. Ben Zorn","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_zorn_007.mp3","published":"2018-01-03T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

In an era of AI breakthroughs and other exciting advances in computer science, Dr. Ben Zorn would like to remind us that behind every great technical revolution is a‚Ä¶ programming language. As a Principal Researcher and the Co-director of RiSE ‚Äì or Research in Software Engineering ‚Äì group at Microsoft Research, Dr. Zorn has dedicated his life to making sure the software that now touches nearly everything in our lives is easy, accurate, reliable and secure. Today, Dr. Zorn tells us some great stories about bugs and whales, warns us against the dumb side of ‚Äúsmart‚Äù objects, shares about his group‚Äôs attempt to scale the Everest of software security, and makes a great case that the most important programming language in the world today is‚Ä¶ the spreadsheet.

","hash":"17bf06c9fa6c2d9067e6ce86839977f5","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"721d98d7-79c4-48dd-9a93-a1abaa5087bf","title":"005 - Visualizing Data and Other Big Ideas with Dr. Steven Drucker","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_drucker_005.mp3","published":"2017-12-20T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"\n

In a wide-ranging interview, veteran Microsoft Researcher, Dr. Steven Drucker talks about his work in data visualization, the importance of clear communication in a world of complex algorithms and big data, and the long, slow work of big breakthroughs. He also offers some pro-tips to aspiring researchers, and tells us why stand-up comedy is an important skill for computer scientists.

\n","hash":"c0fa9a9456d1742144055468262359d6","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"859992db-3fc7-4b0c-9b2f-353e8f0a862a","title":"004 - Getting Virtual with Dr. Mar Gonzalez Franco","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_franco_004.mp3","published":"2017-12-13T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"\n

On today‚Äôs episode, neuroscientist and virtual reality researcher, Dr. Mar Gonzalez Franco, talks about her work in VR, explains how avatars can help increase our empathy and reduce our biases via role play, and addresses the misconceptions that exist between the immersive experiences of virtual reality and psychedelic drugs.

\n\n

","hash":"fa523308344a3e29e282ab2a312c7520","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"55bef67a-0f4e-4878-85ae-f3c2bc44b235","title":"003 - Hybrid Reward Architecture and the Fall of Ms. Pac-Man with Dr. Harm van Seijen","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_vanseijen_003.mp3","published":"2017-12-06T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôve ever watched King of Kong: Fistful of Quarters, you know what a big deal it is to beat a video arcade game that was designed not to lose. Most humans can‚Äôt even come close. Enter Harm van Seijen, and a team of machine learning researchers from Microsoft Maluuba in Montreal. They took on Ms. Pac-man. And won. Today we‚Äôll talk to Harm about his work in reinforcement learning, the inspiration for hybrid reward architecture, visit a few islands of tractability and get an inside look at the science behind the AI defeat of one of the most difficult video arcade games around.

","hash":"24ae51d736aa96492d58ccbf82841c5f","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"4b8a262f-f542-4c9d-ae17-ee59f35f0638","title":"002 - AI and Our Future with Machines with Dr. Eric Horvitz","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_horvitz_002.mp3","published":"2017-12-04T05:51:00Z","show_notes":"

When it comes to artificial intelligence, Dr. Eric Horvitz is as passionate as he is accomplished. His contributions to the field, and service on the boards of nearly every technical academy and association in the country, have earned him the respect ‚Äì and awe ‚Äì of his colleagues, along with the position of Technical Fellow and Managing Director of Microsoft Research. Today, Dr. Horvitz talks about the goal of artificial intelligence, his vision for our collaborative future with machines, what we can learn from the Wright brothers, and how a short stint of ‚Äúsix months, maximum‚Äù became an illustrious and, in his words, joyful, 25-year career at Microsoft Research.

","hash":"929736483b26335efd9df41e35368455","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"4d9877dd-3744-41e9-b8a8-3510ead946a6","title":"001 - Notes from the Productivity Revolution with Dr. Jaime Teevan","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_teevan_001.mp3","published":"2017-11-27T18:15:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. Jaime Teevan has a lot to say about productivity in a fragmented culture, and some solutions that seem promising, if somewhat counter-intuitive. Dr. Teevan is a Microsoft researcher, University of Washington Affiliate Professor, and the mother of four young boys. Today she talks about what she calls the productivity revolution, and explains how her research in micro-productivity ‚Äì making use of short fragments of time to help us accomplish larger tasks -¬† could help us be more productive, and experience a better quality of life at the same time.

Members of the research community at Microsoft work continuously to advance their respective fields. Abstracts brings its audience to the cutting edge with them through short, compelling conversations about new and noteworthy achievements.

In this episode, Senior Researchers Jordan Ash and Dipendra Misra join host Gretchen Huizinga to discuss ‚ÄúThe Truth is in There: Improving Reasoning in Language Models with Layer-Selective Rank Reduction,‚Äù which was accepted to the 2024 International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). Layer-Selective Rank reduction, or LASER, is an intervention for targeted parameter reduction in transformer-based models. The work shows that the removal of certain parameters not only maintains model performance like some existing parameter-reduction methods but can actually improve it‚Äîno additional training necessary.

To learn more about the paper and related topics, register for Microsoft Research Forum, a series of panel discussions and lightning talks around science and technology research in the era of general AI.

Powerful large-scale AI models like GPT-4 are showing dramatic improvements in reasoning, problem-solving, and language capabilities. This marks a phase change for artificial intelligence‚Äîand a signal of accelerating progress to come.

In this Microsoft Research Podcast series, AI scientist and engineer Ashley Llorens hosts conversations with his collaborators and colleagues about what these models‚Äîand the models that will come next‚Äîmean for our approach to creating, understanding, and deploying AI, its applications in areas such as healthcare and education, and its potential to benefit humanity.

This episode features Technical Fellow Christopher Bishop, who leads a global team of researchers and engineers working to help accelerate scientific discovery by merging machine learning and the natural sciences. Llorens and Bishop explore the state of deep learning; Bishop‚Äôs new textbook Deep Learning: Foundations and Concepts, his third and a writing collaboration with his son; and a potential future in which ‚Äúsuper copilots‚Äù accessible via natural language and drawing on a variety of tools, like those that can simulate the fundamental equations of nature, are empowering scientists in their pursuit of breakthrough.

Powerful large-scale AI models like GPT-4 are showing dramatic improvements in reasoning, problem-solving, and language capabilities. This marks a phase change for artificial intelligence‚Äîand a signal of accelerating progress to come.

In this Microsoft Research Podcast series, AI scientist and engineer Ashley Llorens hosts conversations with his collaborators and colleagues about what these models‚Äîand the models that will come next‚Äîmean for our approach to creating, understanding, and deploying AI, its applications in areas such as healthcare and education, and its potential to benefit humanity.

This episode features Partner Research Manager Hanna Wallach, whose research into fairness, accountability, transparency, and ethics in AI and machine learning has helped inform the use of AI in Microsoft products and services for years. Wallach describes how she and a team of applied scientists expanded their tools for measuring fairness-related harms in AI systems to address harmful content more broadly during their involvement in the deployment of Bing Chat; her interest in filtering, a technique for mitigating harms that she describes as widely used but not often talked about; and the cross-company collaboration that brings policy, engineering, and research together to evolve and execute the Microsoft approach to developing and deploying AI responsibly.

Learn more:¬†

Microsoft AI: Responsible AI Principles and Approach¬†¬†

AI and Microsoft Research¬†

Powerful new large-scale AI models like GPT-4 are showing dramatic improvements in reasoning, problem-solving, and language capabilities. This marks a phase change for artificial intelligence‚Äîand a signal of accelerating progress to come.

In this Microsoft Research Podcast series, AI scientist and engineer Ashley Llorens hosts conversations with his collaborators and colleagues about what these new models‚Äîand the models that will come next‚Äîmean for our approach to creating, understanding, and deploying AI, its applications in areas such as health care and education, and its potential to benefit humanity.

This episode features Senior Principal Researcher Emre Kiciman and Principal Researcher Amit Sharma, whose paper ‚ÄúCausal Reasoning and Large Language Models: Opening a New Frontier for Causality‚Äù examines the causal capabilities of large language models (LLMs) and their implications. Kiciman and Sharma break down the study of cause and effect; recount their respective ongoing journeys with GPT-3.5 and GPT-4‚Äîfrom their preconceptions to where they are now‚Äîand share their views of a future in which LLMs help bring together different modes of reasoning in the practice of causal inference and make causal methods easier to adopt.

For Microsoft researchers, COVID-19 was a call to action. The reimagining of work practices had long been an area of study, but existing and new questions that needed immediate answers surfaced as companies and their employees quickly adjusted to significantly different working conditions. Teams from across the Microsoft organizational chart pooled their unique expertise together under The New Future of Work initiative. The results have informed product features designed to better support remote work and are now being used to help companies, including Microsoft, usher their workforces into a future of hybrid work.

\n

In this episode of The New Future of Work series, Chief Scientist Jaime Teevan and Senior Principal Researcher Siddharth Suri explore the many ways people were impacted by work shifts during the COVID-19 pandemic. They talk about how race, gender, income, and other factors are indicative of how people have fared and what this means for the future of work. The researchers discuss the importance of examining potential hidden consequences‚Äîand patience‚Äîwhen using short-term data to make long-term decisions, emphasizing aspects of burnout and innovation.‚ÄØTopics covered in this wide-ranging conversation include‚ÄØbenefits of commutes and a silver lining in the shift to remote‚ÄØand hybrid work‚Äîthe movement of more innovative jobs out of large metro areas, creating momentum for greater opportunity‚ÄØin‚ÄØdiverse‚ÄØlocations. The research that Siddharth Suri describes in this podcast was jointly done with Hana Wolf of LinkedIn.

\n

","hash":"fba7fdb4b10d149b2f93f7d8840c8c01","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0bca0a46-e0f0-43cb-a019-76303b0d6f93","title":"124 - Econ4: Uncovering how decision-making shapes individuals and society through behavioral public economics featuring Evan Rose and Hunt Allcott","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/MSR_124_ROSE_ALLCOTT.mp3","published":"2021-06-16T15:55:00Z","show_notes":"

In the world of economics, researchers at Microsoft are examining a range of complex systems‚Äîfrom those that impact the technologies we use to those that inform the laws and policies we create‚Äîthrough the lens of a social science that goes beyond the numbers to better understand people and society.

\n

\n

In this episode, Senior Principal Researcher¬†Hunt Allcott talks with Postdoctoral Researcher Evan Rose about Allcott‚Äôs work exploring the everyday decisions people face, like buying fuel-efficient cars or taking out payday loans, and how a clearer understanding of these decisions can shape meaningful public policy. Allcott shares how his and others‚Äô research shows that policy can often have complex outcomes resulting in hidden benefits and drawbacks, as in the case of taxes on sugary beverages. The researchers also discuss why individuals often feel the competing motivations of making bad versus good decisions‚Äîa tension that often lies front-and-center in scenarios primed for behavioral public economics research.

\n

In the world of economics, researchers at Microsoft are examining a range of complex systems‚Äîfrom those that impact the technologies we use to those that inform the laws and policies we create‚Äîthrough the lens of a social science that goes beyond the numbers to better understand people and society.

\nhttps://www.microsoft.com/research","hash":"9ca3e565164a01e8e9fe550d17453787","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"26900727-8b55-4a60-a6bd-0817321f1b28","title":"120 - Advancing Excel as a programming language with Andy Gordon and Simon Peyton Jones","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/MSR_002_LAMBDA_simon_andy_v2.mp3","published":"2021-05-05T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Today, people around the globe‚Äîfrom teachers to small-business owners to finance executives‚Äîuse Microsoft Excel to make sense of the information that occupies their respective worlds, and whether they realize it or not, in doing so, they‚Äôre taking on the role of programmer.

They‚Äôll talk specifically about how research has influenced Excel and vice versa, programming as a human-computer interaction challenge, and a future in which Excel is the first language for budding programmers and a tool for incorporating probabilistic reasoning into our decision-making.

","hash":"eca24bc7a51bed0c11537da76abf7d73","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"9b96e8a2-fcfc-40d0-80bc-23a786fea47e","title":"119 - Defending DRAM for data safety and security in the cloud","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_saroiu_119.mp3","published":"2020-07-08T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dynamic random-access memory ‚Äì or DRAM ‚Äì is the most popular form of volatile computer memory in the world but it‚Äôs particularly susceptible to Rowhammer, an adversarial attack that can cause data loss and security exploits in everything from smart phones to the cloud.

\n

Today, Dr. Stefan Saroiu, a Senior Principal Researcher in MSR‚Äôs Mobility and Networking group, explains why DRAM remains vulnerable to Rowhammer attacks today, even after several years of mitigation efforts, and then tells us how a new approach involving bespoke extensibility mechanisms for DRAM might finally hammer Rowhammer in the fight to keep data safe and secure.

","hash":"7ffd4838ac38e2aa726122e8bd16142a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"57c963cc-a2f4-42e4-9559-2423b8c4c743","title":"078r - Machine teaching with Dr. Patrice Simard","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_simard_078r.mp3","published":"2020-01-15T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode originally aired in May, 2019.

\n

Machine learning is a powerful tool that enables computers to learn by observing the world, recognizing patterns and self-training via experience. Much like humans. But while machines perform well when they can extract knowledge from large amounts of labeled data, their learning outcomes remain vastly inferior to humans when data is limited. That‚Äôs why Dr. Patrice Simard, Distinguished Engineer and head of the Machine Teaching group at Microsoft, is using actual teachers to help machines learn, and enable them to extract knowledge from humans rather than just data.

\n

Today, Dr. Simard tells us why he believes any task you can teach to a human, you should be able to teach to a machine; explains how machines can exploit the human ability to decompose and explain concepts to train ML models more efficiently and less expensively; and gives us an innovative vision of how, when a human teacher and a machine learning model work together in a real-time interactive process, domain experts can leverage the power of machine learning without machine learning expertise.

\n","hash":"3df6203fd97d070a1acdc5cefcd7d516","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"3248ba85-9a17-4906-9533-cd86374b0a85","title":"077r - The productive software engineer with Dr. Tom Zimmermann","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_zimmermann_077r.mp3","published":"2020-01-08T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode originally aired in May, 2019.

\n

If you‚Äôre in software development, Dr. Tom Zimmermann, a senior researcher at Microsoft Research in Redmond, wants you to be more productive, and he‚Äôs here to help. How, you might ask? Well, while productivity can be hard to measure, his research in the Empirical Software Engineering group is attempting to do just that by using insights from actual data, rather than just gut feelings, to improve the software development process.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Zimmermann talks about why we need to rethink productivity in software engineering, explains why work environments matter, tells us how AI and machine learning are impacting traditional software workflows, and reveals the difference between a typical day and a good day in the life of a software developer, and what it would take to make a good day typical!

\n","hash":"32ed664163c5a15a555afa762c877044","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"9bbfdb89-1613-4a16-aef3-ee5f06e61b59","title":"075r - Reinforcement learning for the real world with Dr. John Langford and Rafah Hosn","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_langford_hosn_075r.mp3","published":"2020-01-01T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode originally aired in May, 2019.
Dr. John Langford, a partner researcher in the Machine Learning group at Microsoft Research New York City, is a reinforcement learning expert who is working, in his own words, to solve machine learning. Rafah Hosn, also of MSR New York, is a principal program manager who‚Äôs working to take that work to the world. If that sounds like big thinking in the Big Apple, well, New York City has always been a ‚Äúgo big, or go home‚Äù kind of town, and MSR NYC is a ‚Äúgo big, or go home‚Äù kind of lab.

\n

Today, Dr. Langford explains why online reinforcement learning is critical to solving machine learning and how moving from the current foundation of a Markov decision process toward a contextual bandit future might be part of the solution. Rafah Hosn talks about why it‚Äôs important, from a business perspective, to move RL agents out of simulated environments and into the open world, and gives us an under-the-hood look at the product side of MSR‚Äôs ‚Äúresearch, incubate, transfer‚Äù process, focusing on real world reinforcement learning which, at Microsoft, is now called Azure Cognitive Services Personalizer.

\n","hash":"8228c2b09e1edfe2faff3c5fd18a6517","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"40b4a553-eedf-41ed-b2c6-e2a251890fa4","title":"053r - Chasing convex bodies and other random topics with Dr. S√©bastien Bubeck","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_bubeck_053r.mp3","published":"2019-12-25T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. S√©bastien Bubeck is a mathematician and a senior researcher in the Machine Learning and Optimization group at Microsoft Research. He‚Äôs also a self-proclaimed ‚Äúbandit‚Äù who claims that, despite all the buzz around AI, it‚Äôs still a science in its infancy. That‚Äôs why he‚Äôs devoted his career to advancing the mathematical foundations behind the machine learning algorithms behind AI.

\n

Today, Dr. Bubeck explains the difficulty of the multi-armed bandit problem in the context of a parameter- and data-rich online world. He also discusses a host of topics from randomness and convex optimization to metrical task systems and log n competitiveness to the surprising connection between Gaussian kernels and what he calls some of the most beautiful objects in mathematics.

\nhttps://www.microsoft.com/research\n","hash":"75bb20f5eff93defa46db5ce2bc2f564","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"deeed867-67f3-48e9-abc3-4aabcb5affb6","title":"052r - Chris Bishop","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_bishop_052r.mp3","published":"2019-12-18T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. Christopher Bishop is quite a fellow. Literally. Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering. Fellow of Darwin College in Cambridge, England. Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. Fellow of The Royal Society. Microsoft Technical Fellow. And one of the nicest fellows you‚Äôre likely to meet! With all the buzz surrounding AI, it can be tempting to envision it as a stand-alone entity that optimizes for accuracy and displaces human capabilities. On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Nushi talks about what it takes to develop collaborative AI systems and unpacks the unique challenges machine learning engineers face in their version of the software development cycle. She also reveals why understanding the ‚Äúterrain of failure‚Äù can help researchers develop AI systems that perform as well in the real world as they do in the lab.

Deep learning methodologies like supervised learning have been very successful in training machines to make predictions about the world. Machine learning is a powerful tool that enables conversational agents to provide general question-answer services. But in domains with more specific taxonomies ‚Äì or simply for requests that are longer and more complicated than ‚ÄúPlay Baby Shark‚Äù ‚Äì custom conversational AI has long been the province of large enterprises with big budgets. But not for long, thanks to the work of Dr. Riham Mansour, a Principal Software Engineering Manager for Microsoft‚Äôs Language Understanding Service, or LUIS. ","hash":"d517e45de3ab5409a9dbc7cdcc960d50","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0166c48d-e086-4011-8ce1-07aa63ba7c76","title":"094 - News from the front in the post-quantum crypto wars with Dr. Craig Costello","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_costello_094.mp3","published":"2019-10-16T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. Craig Costello is in the business of safeguarding your secrets. And he uses math to do it. A researcher in the Security and Cryptography group at Microsoft Research, Dr. Costello is among a formidable group of code makers (aka cryptographers) who make it their life‚Äôs work to protect the internet against adversarial code breakers (aka cryptanalysts), both those that exist today in our classical computing world, and those that will exist in a quantum computing future.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Costello gives us a battlefield update in the ongoing crypto wars; talks about different approaches to post quantum cryptography and explains why he believes isogeny-based primitives are among the most promising; and reassures us that, as long as the battle goes on, cryptographers will continue to work very hard on the very hard math they hope will protect us from hackers and attackers, even in the age of quantum computers.

As computing moves to the cloud, there is an increasing need for privacy in AI. In an ideal world, users would have the ability to compute on encrypted data without sacrificing performance. Enter Dr. Olli Saarikivi, a post-doctoral researcher in the RiSE group at MSR. He, along with a stellar group of cross-disciplinary colleagues, are bridging the gap with CHET, a compiler and runtime for homomorphic evaluation of tensor programs, that keeps data private while making the complexities of homomorphic encryption schemes opaque to users.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Saarikivi tells us all about CHET, gives us an overview of some of his other projects, including Parasail, a novel approach to parallelizing seemingly sequential applications, and tells us how a series of unconventional educational experiences shaped his view of himself, and his career as a researcher.

This episode first aired in January, 2018. When we look at a skyscraper or a suspension bridge, a simple search engine box on a screen looks tiny by comparison. Today, Dr. Peyton Jones shares his passion for functional programming research, reveals how a desire to help other researchers write and present better turned him into an unlikely YouTube star, and explains why, at least in the world of programming languages, purity is embarrassing, laziness is cool, and success should be avoided at all costs.

This episode first aired in March, 2018. There‚Äôs a big gap between memory and storage, and Dr. Anirudh Badam, of the Systems Research Group at Microsoft Research, wants to close it. With projects like Navamem, which explores how systems can get faster and better by adopting new memory technologies, and HashCache, which brings with it the promise of storage for the next billion, he just might do it.

Today, Dr. Badam discusses the historic trade-offs between volatile and non-volatile memory, shares how software-defined batteries are changing the power-supply landscape, talks about how his research is aiming for the trifecta of speed, cost and capacity in new memory technologies, and reminds us, once again, how one good high school physics teacher can inspire the next generation of scientific discovery.

Dr. Johannes Gehrke is a Microsoft Technical Fellow and head of Architecture and Machine Learning for the Intelligent Communications and Conversations Cloud in Microsoft‚Äôs Experiences and Devices division. ","hash":"1d3a7ce3e7d556882ff6e6fee7bcebca","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"b8764cc1-d4bf-4cd3-a928-e9cb79a9d72f","title":"001r - Snippets from the Revolution ‚Äì An Interview with Dr. Jaime Teevan","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_teevan_001rr.mp3","published":"2019-07-10T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

","hash":"b899b728b7d2bbc87a147bd0d5372273","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"cb64327b-1b0b-4b6c-8438-64ee867aa7aa","title":"009r - Life at the Intersection of AI and Society with Dr. Ece Kamar","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_kamar_009r.mp3","published":"2019-07-03T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

As the reality of artificial intelligence continues to capture our imagination, and critical AI systems enter our world at a rapid pace, Dr. Ece Kamar, a senior researcher in the Adaptive Systems and Interaction Group at Microsoft Research, is working to help us understand AI‚Äôs far-reaching implications, both as we use it, and as we build it.

Today, Dr. Kamar talks about the complementarity between humans and machines, debunks some common misperceptions about AI, reveals how we can overcome bias and blind spots by putting humans in the AI loop, and argues convincingly that, despite everything machines can do (and they can do a lot), humans are still ‚Äúthe real deal.‚Äù

","hash":"0a7b87cac4cdd87ba5344013f171a842","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"33328b0d-774d-4287-bc46-61f5adda1bde","title":"082 - The brave new world of cloud-scale systems and networking with Dr. Lidong Zhou","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_082_zhou.mp3","published":"2019-06-26T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôre like me, you‚Äôre no longer amazed by how all your technologies can work for you. Rather, you‚Äôve begun to take for granted that they simply should work for you. Instantly. All together. ","hash":"987413f3328617614cebdf7195aa9572","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"e163e860-2968-4ec4-8ded-9f87abd921ae","title":"081 - Game on with Dr. Chris Bishop and Phil Spencer","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_081_spencer_bishop.mp3","published":"2019-06-19T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. Chris Bishop is a Microsoft Technical Fellow and director of MSR Cambridge, where he oversees an impressive portfolio of research including machine learning, AI, healthcare and gaming. ","hash":"8199454090eefb7d96e7b67a65c7da4e","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0c410037-e24e-4f71-8c62-7b10221acc2b","title":"080 - All Data AI with Dr. Andrew Fitzgibbon","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_080_fitzgibbon.mp3","published":"2019-06-12T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

You may not know who Dr. Andrew Fitzgibbon is, but if you‚Äôve watched a TV show or movie in the last two decades, you‚Äôve probably seen some of his work. An expert in 3D computer vision and graphics, and head of the new All Data AI group at Microsoft Research Cambridge, Dr. Fitzgibbon was instrumental in the development of Boujou, an Emmy Award-winning 3D camera tracker that lets filmmakers place virtual props, like the floating candles in Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry, into live-action footage. But that was just his warm-up act.

","hash":"d82c57e17e833501e6b4a35133da88e0","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"2b13891d-81f1-47e8-9974-9f854938e9df","title":"079 - Making the most of micro-moments with Dr. Shamsi Iqbal","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_079_iqbal.mp3","published":"2019-06-05T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôve recently found it more difficult to focus your attention for a lengthy stretch of time in order to get a complex task done‚Ä¶ or worse, found it difficult even to find a lengthy stretch of time in which to try, you‚Äôre not alone. And actually, you‚Äôre in luck. Dr. Shamsi Iqbal, a senior researcher in the Information and Data Sciences group at Microsoft Research, wants to help you manage your attention better and be more productive at the same time. And she‚Äôs using technology to do it!

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Iqbal tells us about her work in the field of micro-productivity, a line of research that takes aim at the short spurts of time she calls micro-moments that we otherwise might have considered too short to get anything useful done. She also explains why distraction can be good for us and gives us some advice on how to make the most of our cognitive resources, whether by setting aside time to tackle big tasks in the traditional way or by breaking them down into micro-tasks‚Ä¶ and ‚Äúoutsourcing‚Äù them to ourselves!

","hash":"a3d81b6d4925d7a82cb0ccb83a3bf5de","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"36f2e450-900f-4e73-879e-38f019b7b8af","title":"078 - Machine teaching with Dr. Patrice Simard","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_078_simard.mp3","published":"2019-05-29T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Machine learning is a powerful tool that enables computers to learn by observing the world, recognizing patterns and self-training via experience. Much like humans. But while machines perform well when they can extract knowledge from large amounts of labeled data, their learning outcomes remain vastly inferior to humans when data is limited. That‚Äôs why Dr. Patrice Simard, Distinguished Engineer and head of the Machine Teaching group at Microsoft, is using actual teachers to help machines learn, and enable them to extract knowledge from humans rather than just data.

\n

Today, Dr. Simard tells us why he believes any task you can teach to a human, you should be able to teach to a machine; explains how machines can exploit the human ability to decompose and explain concepts to train ML models more efficiently and less expensively; and gives us an innovative vision of how, when a human teacher and a machine learning model work together in a real-time interactive process, domain experts can leverage the power of machine learning without machine learning expertise.

","hash":"75f2ce03f3d060e31ad10207e2a59c81","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"3f797c36-749b-4d0b-8f3d-5c92d4054523","title":"077 - The productive software engineer with Dr. Tom Zimmermann","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_077_zimmermann.mp3","published":"2019-05-22T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôre in software development, Dr. Tom Zimmermann, a senior researcher at Microsoft Research in Redmond, wants you to be more productive, and he‚Äôs here to help. How, you might ask? Well, while productivity can be hard to measure, his research in the Empirical Software Engineering group is attempting to do just that by using insights from actual data, rather than just gut feelings, to improve the software development process.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Zimmermann talks about why we need to rethink productivity in software engineering, explains why work environments matter, tells us how AI and machine learning are impacting traditional software workflows, and reveals the difference between a typical day and a good day in the life of a software developer, and what it would take to make a good day typical!

","hash":"b134b3b2bee9c4b24f9512fc937e5269","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"135bca83-b8d2-4fcc-8313-971159ed8eb7","title":"076 - Speech and language: the crown jewel of AI with Dr. Xuedong Huang","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_076_huang.mp3","published":"2019-05-15T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When was the last time you had a meaningful conversation with your computer‚Ä¶ and felt like it truly understood you? Well, if Dr. Xuedong Huang, a Microsoft Technical Fellow and head of Microsoft‚Äôs Speech and Language group, is successful, you will. And if his track record holds true, it‚Äôll be sooner than you think!

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Huang talks about his role as Microsoft‚Äôs Chief Speech Scientist, gives us some inside details on the latest milestones in speech and language technology, and explains how mastering speech recognition, translation and conversation will move machines further along the path from ‚Äúperceptive AI‚Äù to ‚Äúcognitive AI‚Äù and that much closer to truly human intelligence.

","hash":"b98d1726629a07e9760c68ce34dd4676","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"05ae5ba0-c1a1-4288-9c81-635c07d25df1","title":"075 - Reinforcement learning for the real world with Dr. John Langford and Rafah Hosn","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_075_langford_hosn.mp3","published":"2019-05-08T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Dr. John Langford, a partner researcher in the Machine Learning group at Microsoft Research New York City, is a reinforcement learning expert who is working, in his own words, to solve machine learning. Rafah Hosn, also of MSR New York, is a principal program manager who‚Äôs working to take that work to the world. If that sounds like big thinking in the Big Apple, well, New York City has always been a ‚Äúgo big, or go home‚Äù kind of town, and MSR NYC is a ‚Äúgo big, or go home‚Äù kind of lab.

\n

Today, Dr. Langford explains why online reinforcement learning is critical to solving machine learning and how moving from the current foundation of a Markov decision process toward a contextual bandit future might be part of the solution. Rafah Hosn talks about why it‚Äôs important, from a business perspective, to move RL agents out of simulated environments and into the open world, and gives us an under-the-hood look at the product side of MSR‚Äôs ‚Äúresearch, incubate, transfer‚Äù process, focusing on real world reinforcement learning which, at Microsoft, is now called Azure Cognitive Services Personalizer.

","hash":"498a036202c4a42eafe2ff4875f05f75","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"fa617142-a834-4669-af59-40d6fa910917","title":"074 - CHI squared with Dr. Ken Hinckley and Dr. Meredith Ringel Morris","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_074_Hinkley_Morris_2.mp3","published":"2019-05-01T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you want to know what‚Äôs going on in the world of human computer interaction research, or what‚Äôs new at the CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, you should hang out with Dr. Ken Hinckley, a principal researcher and research manager in the EPIC group at Microsoft Research, and Dr. Merrie Ringel Morris, a principal researcher and research manager in the Ability group. Both are prolific HCI researchers who are seeking, from different angles, to augment the capability of technologies and improve the experiences people have with them.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, we get to hang out with both Dr. Hinckley and Dr. Morris as they talk about life at the intersection of hardware, software and human potential, discuss how computers can enhance human lives, especially in some of the most marginalized populations, and share their unique approaches to designing and building technologies that really work for people and for society.

","hash":"0076e927b489c5fe89b6fdc0f72d49f4","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"fa90c5ee-4e00-4dcc-b46f-fb255c7e2f8d","title":"073 - Froid and the relational database query quandry with Dr. Karthik Ramachandra","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_073_ramachandra.mp3","published":"2019-04-24T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

In the world of relational databases, structured query language, or SQL, has long been King of the Queries, primarily because of its ubiquity and unparalleled performance. But many users prefer a mix of imperative programming, along with declarative SQL, because its user-defined functions (or UDFs) allow for good software engineering practices like modularity, readability and re-usability. Sadly, these benefits have traditionally come with a huge performance penalty, rendering them impractical in most situations. That bothered Dr. Karthik Ramachandra, a Senior Applied Scientist at Microsoft Research India, so he‚Äôs spent a great deal of his career working on improving an imperative complement to SQL in database systems.

\n

Today, Dr. Ramachandra gives us an overview of the historic trade-offs between declarative and imperative programming paradigms, tells us some fantastic stories, including The Tale of Two Engineers and The UDF Story, Parts 1 and 2, and introduces us to Froid ‚Äì that‚Äôs F-R-O-I-D, not the Austrian psychoanalyst ‚Äì which is an extensible, language-agnostic framework for optimizing imperative functions in databases, offering the benefits of UDFs without sacrificing performance.

","hash":"5cea65968851148d22ce91d594b45226","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"5d570cf6-6ba1-49bd-b548-1f28efd79f07","title":"072 - AI for Earth with Dr. Lucas Joppa","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_072_joppa.mp3","published":"2019-04-17T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

We hear a lot these days about ‚ÄúAI for good‚Äù and the efforts of many companies to harness the power of artificial intelligence to solve some of our biggest environmental challenges. It‚Äôs rare, however, that you find a company willing to bring its environmental bona fides all the way to the C Suite. Well, meet Dr. Lucas Joppa. A former environmental and computer science researcher at MSR who was tapped in 2017 to become the company‚Äôs first Chief Environmental Scientist, Dr. Joppa is now the Chief Environmental Officer at Microsoft, another first, and is responsible for managing the company‚Äôs overall environmental sustainability efforts from operations to policy to technology.

\n

Today, Dr. Joppa shares how his love for nature and the joy of discovery actually helped shape his career path, and tells us all about AI for Earth, a multi-year, multi-million dollar initiative to deploy the full scale of Microsoft‚Äôs products, policies and partnerships across four key areas of agriculture, water, biodiversity and climate, and transform the way society monitors, models, and ultimately manages Earth‚Äôs natural resources.

","hash":"83e6de7c4fa02bd50c76d1a0fe33fc4a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"d4f7ab9e-ef2f-40a2-aae2-5cc5607774a1","title":"071 - Holograms, spatial anchors and the future of computer vision with Dr. Marc Pollefeys","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_071_pollefeys.mp3","published":"2019-04-10T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

Dr. Marc Pollefeys is a Professor of Computer Science at ETH Zurich, a Partner Director of Science for Microsoft, and the Director of a new Microsoft Mixed Reality and AI lab in Switzerland. He‚Äôs a leader in the field of computer vision research, but it‚Äôs hard to pin down whether his work is really about the future of computer vision, or about a vision of future computers. Arguably, it‚Äôs both!

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Pollefeys brings us up to speed on the latest in computer vision research, including his innovative work with Azure Spatial Anchors, tells us how devices like Kinect and HoloLens may have cut their teeth in gaming, but turned out to be game changers for both research and industrial applications, and explains how, while it‚Äôs still early days now, in the future, you‚Äôre much more likely to put your computer on your head than on your desk or your lap.

","hash":"bdd6b115550afd334dd99817259f40a0","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"fac104c5-477a-4a56-bb85-7193e5cacdc7","title":"070 - Enabling design with Ann Paradiso","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_070_paradiso.mp3","published":"2019-04-03T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Ann Paradiso is an interaction designer and the Principal User Experience Designer for the NExT Enable group at Microsoft Research. She‚Äôs also the epitome of a phrase she often uses to describe other people: a force of nature. Together with a diverse array of team members and collaborators, many of whom have ALS or other conditions that affect mobility and speech, Ann works on new interaction paradigms for assistive technologies hoping to make a more bespoke approach to technology solutions accessible, at scale, to the people who need it most.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Ann tells us all about life in the extreme constraint design lane, explains what a PALS is, and tells us some incredibly entertaining stories about how the eye tracking technology behind the Eye Controlled Wheelchair and the Hands-Free Music Project has made its way from Microsoft‚Äôs campus to some surprising events around the country, including South by Southwest and Mardi Gras.

","hash":"1647d8630285ef1a6103d20b08b5e6bf","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"844abbf2-1412-4894-9aa5-df64dddf4b9d","title":"069 - All about automated machine learning with Dr. Nicolo Fusi","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_069_fusi_RERUN.mp3","published":"2019-03-27T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in September, 2018:

\n

You may have heard the phrase, necessity is the mother of invention, but for Dr. Nicolo Fusi, a researcher at the Microsoft Research lab in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the mother of his invention wasn‚Äôt so much necessity as it was boredom: the special machine learning boredom of manually fine-tuning models and hyper-parameters that can eat up tons of human and computational resources, but bring no guarantee of a good result. His solution? Automate machine learning with a meta-model that figures out what other models are doing, and then predicts how they‚Äôll work on a given dataset.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Fusi gives us an inside look at Automated Machine Learning ‚Äì Microsoft‚Äôs version of the industry‚Äôs AutoML technology ‚Äì and shares the story of how an idea he had while working on a gene editing problem with CRISPR/Cas9 turned into a bit of a machine learning side quest and, ultimately, a surprisingly useful instantiation of Automated Machine Learning ‚Äì now a feature of Azure Machine Learning ‚Äì that reduces dependence on intuition and takes some of the tedium out of data science at the same time.

","hash":"1582a645e27fcf87455d3e706dcee663","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ca39df4d-bbad-4011-9660-62e6502fc9bb","title":"068 - Project Triton and the physics of sound with Dr. Nikunj Raghuvanshi","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_068_raghuvanshi.mp3","published":"2019-03-20T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôve ever played video games, you know that for the most part, they look a lot better than they sound. That‚Äôs largely due to the fact that audible sound waves are much longer ‚Äì and a lot more crafty ‚Äì than visual light waves, and therefore, much more difficult to replicate in simulated environments. But Dr. Nikunj Raghuvanshi, a Senior Researcher in the Interactive Media Group at Microsoft Research, is working to change that by bringing the quality of game audio up to speed with the quality of game video. He wants you to hear how sound really travels ‚Äì in rooms, around corners, behind walls, out doors ‚Äì and he‚Äôs using computational physics to do it.

\n

Today, Dr. Raghuvanshi talks about the unique challenges of simulating realistic sound on a budget (both money and CPU), explains how classic ideas in concert hall acoustics need a fresh take for complex games like Gears of War, reveals the computational secret sauce you need to deliver the right sound at the right time, and tells us about Project Triton, an acoustic system that models how real sound waves behave in 3-D game environments to makes us believe with our ears as well as our eyes.

","hash":"36018634508c1e897129fa46fd61cd9a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"2d2770d8-6940-4bd9-9b16-5b13303139c5","title":"067 - Programming biology with Dr. Andrew Phillips","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_067_phillips.mp3","published":"2019-03-13T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When we think of information processing systems, we often think of computers, but we ourselves are made up of information processing systems ‚Äì trillions of them ‚Äì also known as the cells in our bodies. While these cells are robust, they‚Äôre also extraordinarily complex and not altogether predictable. Wouldn‚Äôt it be great, asks Dr. Andrew Phillips, head of the Biological Computation Group at Microsoft Research in Cambridge, if we could figure out exactly how these building blocks of life work and harness their power with the rigor and predictability of computer science? To answer that, he‚Äôs spent a good portion of his career working to develop a system of intelligence that can, literally, program biology.

\n

Today, Dr. Phillips talks about the challenges and rewards inherent in reverse engineering biological systems to see how they perform information processing. He also explains what we can learn from stressed out bacteria, and tells us about Station B, a new end-to-end platform his team is working on that aims to reduce the trial and error nature of lab experiments and help scientists turn biological cells into super-factories that could solve some of the most challenging problems in medicine, agriculture, the environment and more.

","hash":"f9dd0fa7a23b2bf775109ab80958137d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"3e5c289c-843c-4882-92d8-a22306ad2583","title":"066 (rerun) - Cryptography for the post-quantum world with Dr. Brian LaMacchia","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_066_LaMachia_RERUN.mp3","published":"2019-03-06T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in August of 2018.

\n

You know those people who work behind the scenes to make sure nothing bad happens to you, and if they‚Äôre really good, you never know who they are because nothing bad happens to you? Well, meet one of those people. Dr. Brian LaMacchia is a Distinguished Engineer and he heads up the Security and Cryptography Group at Microsoft Research. It‚Äôs his job to make sure ‚Äì using up-to-the-minute math ‚Äì that you‚Äôre safe and secure online, both now, and in the post-quantum world to come.

Today, Dr. LaMacchia gives us an inside look at the world of cryptography and the number theory behind it, explains what happens when good algorithms go bad, and tells us why, even though cryptographically relevant quantum computers are still decades away, we need to start developing quantum-resistant algorithms right now.

\n

¬†

","hash":"74ced685c48b3fdc201ec9039d2aeb3d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"08f04911-702f-4e67-9a77-a33373527981","title":"065 - Securing the vote with Dr. Josh Benaloh","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_065_benaloh.mp3","published":"2019-02-27T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôve ever wondered why, in the age of the internet, we still don‚Äôt hold our elections online, you need to spend more time with Dr. Josh Benaloh, Senior Cryptographer at Microsoft Research in Redmond. Josh knows a lot about elections, and even more about homomorphic encryption, the mathematical foundation behind the end-to-end verifiable election systems that can dramatically improve election integrity today and perhaps move us toward wide-scale online voting in the future.

\n

Today, Dr. Benaloh gives us a brief but fascinating history of elections, explains how the trade-offs among privacy, security and verifiability make the relatively easy math of elections such a hard problem for the internet, and tells the story of how the University of Michigan fight song forced the cancellation of an internet voting pilot.

","hash":"f56a45e34e59cf88d67ba4b91001d483","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"5aaa8b96-7c44-47b1-87b5-238d75023c0d","title":"064 - Talking with machines with Dr. Layla El Asri","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_064_el_asri.mp3","published":"2019-02-20T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Humans are unique in their ability to learn from, understand the world through and communicate with language‚Ä¶ Or are they? Perhaps not for long, if Dr. Layla El Asri, a Research Manager at Microsoft Research Montreal, has a say in it. She wants you to be able to talk to your machine just like you‚Äôd talk to another person. That‚Äôs the easy part. The hard part is getting your machine to understand and talk back to you like it‚Äôs that other person.

\n

Today, Dr. El Asri talks about the particular challenges she and other scientists face in building sophisticated dialogue systems that lay the foundation for talking machines. She also explains how reinforcement learning, in the form of a text game generator called TextWorld, is helping us get there, and relates a fascinating story from more than fifty years ago that reveals some of the safeguards necessary to ensure that when we design machines specifically to pass the Turing test, we design them in an ethical and responsible way.

","hash":"c80034305e50412d9143ee472e04f17f","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ffdfb06d-eaf0-4a72-ba99-1222d0858774","title":"063 - Competing in the X Games of machine learning with Dr. Manik Varma","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_063_varma.mp3","published":"2019-02-13T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If every question in life could be answered by choosing from just a few options, machine learning would be pretty simple, and life for machine learning researchers would be pretty sweet. Unfortunately, in both life and machine learning, things are a bit more complicated. That‚Äôs why Dr. Manik Varma, Principal Researcher at MSR India, is developing extreme classification systems to answer multiple-choice questions that have millions of possible options and help people find what they are looking for online more quickly, more accurately and less expensively.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Dr. Varma tells us all about extreme classification (including where in the world you might actually run into 10 or 100 million options), reveals how his Parabel and Slice algorithms are making high quality recommendations in milliseconds, and proves, with both his life and his work, that being blind need not be a barrier to extreme accomplishment.

","hash":"d7a3d71f69e446bf994e12d86d0aa267","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"5743144b-cbd7-457a-9672-887ec77ab3cd","title":"062 - Putting the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù in human computer interaction with Haiyan Zhang","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_062_Zhang-3.mp3","published":"2019-02-06T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Haiyan Zhang is a designer, technologist and maker of things (really cool technical things) who currently holds the unusual title of Innovation Director at the Microsoft Research lab in Cambridge, England. There, she applies her unusual skillset to a wide range of unusual solutions to real-life problems, many of which draw on novel applications of gaming technology in serious areas like healthcare.

\n

On today‚Äôs podcast, Haiyan talks about her unique ‚Äúbrain hack‚Äù approach to the human-centered design process, and discusses a wide range of projects, from the connected play experience of Zanzibar, to Fizzyo, which turns laborious breathing exercises for children with cystic fibrosis into a video game, to Project Emma, an application of haptic vibration technology that, somewhat curiously, offsets the effects of tremors caused by Parkinson‚Äôs disease.

","hash":"77257434fadfb4b20faaa2414e896ef5","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"4ccb2817-a5ab-465f-8350-e9fe910d18c9","title":"061 - Enable(ing) people to do more with Dr. Rico Malvar","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_061_malvar.mp3","published":"2019-01-30T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

From his deep technical roots as a principal researcher and founder of the Communications, Collaboration and Signal Processing group at MSR, through his tenure as Managing Director of the lab in Redmond, to his current role as Distinguished Engineer, Chief Scientist for Microsoft Research and manager of the MSR NExT Enable group, Dr. Rico Malvar has seen ‚Äì and pretty well done ‚Äì it all.

\n

Today, Dr. Malvar recalls his early years at a fledgling Microsoft Research, talks about the exciting work he oversees now, explains why designing with the user is as important as designing for the user, and tells us how a challenge from an ex-football player with ALS led to a prize winning hackathon project and produced the core technology that allows you to type on a keyboard without your hands and drive a wheelchair with your eyes.

","hash":"2454b42d8bf3bd33cd12d7296ff42938","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"9c82240e-850d-46c2-9cd4-a8721a1dfcfa","title":"060 - Empowering people with AI with Dr. Cecily Morrison","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_060_morrison.mp3","published":"2019-01-23T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

You never know how an incident in your own life might inspire a breakthrough in science, but Dr. Cecily Morrison, a researcher in the Human Computer Interaction group at Microsoft Research Cambridge, can attest to how even unexpected events can cause us to see things through a different ‚Äì more inclusive ‚Äì lens and, ultimately, give rise to innovations in research that impact everyone.

\n
