","hash":"4222cb8b88fc7eefa3bd077d94a4466a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"c5506962-9059-477b-ba4e-7da0e385b10c","title":"034 (rerun) - The future is quantum with Dr. Krysta Svore","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_horvitz_033_RERUN.mp3","published":"2018-07-25T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

First aired on January 17, 2018. If someone mentions quantum computing, and you find yourself outwardly nodding your head, but secretly shaking it, you‚Äôre in good company: some of the world‚Äôs smartest people admit they don‚Äôt really understand it either. Fortunately, some of the world‚Äôs other smartest people, like Dr. Krysta Svore, Principal Research Manager of the Microsoft Quantum ‚Äì or QuArC ‚Äì group at Microsoft Research in Redmond, actually DO understand quantum computing, and are working hard to make it a reality.

Today, Dr. Svore shares her passion for quantum algorithms and their potential to solve some of the world‚Äôs biggest problems, explains why Microsoft‚Äôs topological quantum bit ‚Äì or qubit ‚Äì is a game changer for quantum computing, and assures us that, although qubits live in dilution refrigerators at temperatures near absolute zero, quantum researchers can still sit in the comfort of their offices and work with the computer programmer‚Äôs equivalent of Schroedinger‚Äôs Cat.

","hash":"d7d02bff9576930c26be075c939e7616","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"6bd4809d-ba10-450c-abc4-0e0e06770249","title":"032 (rerun) - How Programming Languages Quietly Run the World with Dr. Ben Zorn","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_zorn_RERUN.mp3","published":"2018-07-11T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in January (2018).
In an era of AI breakthroughs and other exciting advances in computer science, Dr. Ben Zorn would like to remind us that behind every great technical revolution is‚Ä¶ a programming language. As a Principal Researcher and the Co-director of RiSE ‚Äì or Research in Software Engineering ‚Äì group at Microsoft Research, Dr. Zorn has dedicated his life to making sure the software that now touches nearly everything in our lives is easy, accurate, reliable and secure. Today, Dr. Zorn tells us some great stories about bugs and whales, warns us against the dumb side of ‚Äúsmart‚Äù objects, shares about his group‚Äôs attempt to scale the Everest of software security, and makes a great case that the most important programming language in the world today is‚Ä¶ the spreadsheet.

","hash":"fd773bc189c8f38d4372b62cd831bd6d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"e8b75408-4cc9-4942-93d7-e4673774b75f","title":"031 (rerun) - AI for the Developing World with Dr. Ranveer Chandra","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_chandra_RERUN.mp3","published":"2018-07-04T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in April (2018).
When we think about artificial intelligence and the ‚Äúworld of the future,‚Äù our vision is usually more Jetsons than Green Acres. But for Dr. Ranveer Chandra, a Principal Researcher in the Systems and Networking group at Microsoft Research, rural farms are the perfect place to realize the benefits of AI through what he calls precision agriculture, or data-driven farming.

Today, in a wide-ranging interview, Dr. Chandra talks about how his research may eventually make your wi-fi signal stronger and your battery life longer, but also shares the story of how spending childhood summers with his grandparents in rural India inspired a line of research that could change the face of farming and help meet the food and nutrition needs of a growing global population.

","hash":"3a9d9657ed3657bacc08910fa99e39f4","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"36693ecb-a537-467c-a269-e82588336f33","title":"030 - Examining the Social Impacts of Artificial Intelligence with Dr. Fernando Diaz","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_diaz_030.mp3","published":"2018-06-27T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Developing complex artificial intelligence systems in a lab is a challenging task, but what happens when they go into production and interact with real humans? That‚Äôs what researchers like Dr. Fernando Diaz, a Principal Research Manager at Microsoft Research Montreal, want to know. He and his colleagues are trying to understand ‚Äì and address ‚Äì the social implications of these systems as they enter the open world.

\n

Today, Dr. Diaz shares his insights on the kinds of questions we need to be asking about artificial intelligence and its impact on society. He also talks about how algorithms can affect your taste in music, and why now, more than ever, computer science education needs to teach ethics along with algorithms.

","hash":"9bd803a1e8aa1f4fca8384363c40268a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0d9b17cb-ade9-49f1-8dbc-a3cc6150dd38","title":"029 (rerun) - Notes from the Productivity Revolution with Dr. Jaime Teevan","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_teevan_RR_029.mp3","published":"2018-06-21T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

This episode first aired in November (2017). Dr. Jaime Teevan has a lot to say about productivity in a fragmented culture, and some solutions that seem promising, if somewhat counter-intuitive. Dr. Teevan is a Microsoft researcher, University of Washington Affiliate Professor, and the mother of four young boys. Today she talks about what she calls the productivity revolution, and explains how her research in micro-productivity ‚Äì making use of short fragments of time to help us accomplish larger tasks -¬† could help us be more productive, and experience a better quality of life at the same time.

","hash":"47ce8e6a5d0fe36e67ec257e52f6ea5a","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"682731ef-4694-46df-86ae-f560d6c51bf9","title":"028 - Teaching Computers to See with Dr. Gang Hua","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_hua_028.mp3","published":"2018-06-13T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

In technical terms, computer vision researchers ‚Äúbuild algorithms and systems to automatically analyze imagery and extract knowledge from the visual world.‚Äù In layman‚Äôs terms, they build machines that can see. And that‚Äôs exactly what Principal Researcher and Research Manager, Dr. Gang Hua, and Computer Vision Technology team, are doing. Because being able to see is really important for things like the personal robots, self-driving cars, and autonomous drones we‚Äôre seeing more and more in our daily lives.

\n

Today, Dr. Hua talks about how the latest advances in AI and machine learning are making big improvements on image recognition, video understanding and even the arts. He also explains the distributed ensemble approach to active learning, where humans and machines work together in the lab to get computer vision systems ready to see and interpret the open world.

","hash":"2c9a75f5c1b46ad7bdf959c1ff867e2e","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"d65d946f-70e5-4039-9e37-c1ec6cd2a91b","title":"027 - The Democratization of Data Science with Dr. Chris White","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_white_027.mp3","published":"2018-06-06T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When we think of medals, we usually picture them over the pocket of a military hero, not over the pocket protector of a computer scientist. That may be because not many academics end up working with the Department of Defense. But Dr. Chris White, now a Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research, has, and he‚Äôs received several awards for his efforts in fighting terrorism and crime with big data, statistics and machine learning.

\n

Today, Dr. White talks about his ‚Äúproblem-first‚Äù approach to research, explains the vital importance of making data understandable for everyone, and shares the story of how a one-week detour from academia turned into an extended tour in Afghanistan, a stint at DARPA, and, eventually, a career at Microsoft Research.

","hash":"a0c3ae35d5f5a2747d4cfd0e9c24e8fa","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"94681246-24d6-4686-ba70-3cfb21e8aab5","title":"026 - Making Intelligence Intelligible with Dr. Rich Caruana","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_caruana_026.mp3","published":"2018-05-30T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

In the world of machine learning, there‚Äôs been a notable trade-off between accuracy and intelligibility. Either the models are accurate but difficult to make sense of, or easy to understand but prone to error. That‚Äôs why Dr. Rich Caruana, Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research, has spent a good part of his career working to make the simple more accurate and the accurate more intelligible.

\n

Today, Dr. Caruana talks about how the rise of deep neural networks has made understanding machine predictions more difficult for humans, and discusses an interesting class of smaller, more interpretable models that may help to make the black box nature of machine learning more transparent.

","hash":"d32f5bbd915b1ea5cacd4723bf3f7b50","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"9db456ba-8804-43dd-9e11-da0e2053232f","title":"025 - Advancing Accessibility with Dr. Meredith Ringel Morris","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_ringelmorris_025.mp3","published":"2018-05-23T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

With 7 billion people on the planet, you might be surprised to learn that approximately a billion of those people experience some form of disability. Enter Principal Researcher and Research Manager, Dr. Merrie Ringel Morris, and the Ability Group at Microsoft Research. They‚Äôre working to remove accessibility barriers both to and through technology, empowering people with disabilities to better perform their daily tasks.

\n

Today, Dr. Morris gives us some fascinating insights into the world of ‚Äúability,‚Äù talks about how technology is augmenting not only sensory and motor abilities, but cognitive and social abilities as well, and shares how Microsoft, through its AI for Accessibility initiative, is committed to extending the capabilities and enhancing the quality of life for every person on the planet.

\n

¬†

","hash":"87e03605c52d710506ba65120c90856e","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"2dc28b51-ac61-4566-8c1e-3e583b608b1c","title":"024 - Not Lost in Translation with Arul Menezes","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_menezes_024.mp3","published":"2018-05-16T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Humans are wired to communicate, but we don‚Äôt always understand each other. Especially when we don‚Äôt speak the same language. But Arul Menezes, the Partner Research Manager who heads MSR‚Äôs Machine Translation team, is working to remove language barriers to help people communicate better. And with the help of some innovative machine learning techniques, and the combined brainpower of machine translation, natural language and machine learning teams in Redmond and Beijing, it‚Äôs happening sooner than anyone expected.

\n

Today, Menezes talks about how the advent of deep learning has enabled exciting advances in machine translation, including applications for people with disabilities, and gives us an inside look at the recent ‚Äúhuman parity‚Äù milestone at Microsoft Research, where machines translated a news dataset from Chinese to English with the same accuracy and quality as a person.

","hash":"b16fb6b7cd5742581112897264eccddc","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"fec31104-6e7e-43a0-b627-2a896e0b1934","title":"023 - Clouds, Catapults and Life After the End of Moore‚Äôs Law with Dr. Doug Burger","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_burger_023.mp3","published":"2018-05-09T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Some of the world‚Äôs leading architects are people that you‚Äôve probably never heard of, and they‚Äôve designed and built some of the world‚Äôs most amazing structures that you‚Äôve probably never seen. Or at least you don‚Äôt think you have. One of these architects is Dr. Doug Burger, Distinguished Engineer at Microsoft Research NExT. And, if you use a computer, or store anything in the Cloud, you‚Äôre a beneficiary of the beautiful architecture that he, and people like him, work on every day.

\n

Today, in a fast-paced interview, Dr. Burger talks about how advances in AI and deep machine learning have placed new acceleration demands on current hardware and computer architecture, offers some observations about the demise of Moore‚Äôs Law, and shares his vision of what life might look like in a post-CPU, post-von-Neumann computing world.

","hash":"13ba020da81c447026f4e17468d6c5a9","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"c612cff9-0330-4b5c-a8f1-69100470ce2a","title":"022 - Machine Learning and the Incredible Flying Robot with Dr. Ashish Kapoor","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_kapoor_022.mp3","published":"2018-05-02T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Autonomous flying agents ‚Äì or flying robots ‚Äì may seem like the stuff of sci-fi to the average person, but to Dr. Ashish Kapoor, Principal Researcher and Research Manager of the Aerial Informatics and Robotics Group at Microsoft Research, they‚Äôre much closer to science than to fiction. And, having built ‚Äì and flight tested ‚Äì his own airplane, complete with state-of-the-art avionics designed to run AI and ML algorithms, he has the street cred ‚Äì or should we say flight cred ‚Äì to prove it.

\n

Today, Dr. Kapoor talks about how cutting-edge machine learning techniques are empowering a new generation of autonomous vehicles, and tells us all about AirSim, an innovative platform that‚Äôs helping bridge the simulator-to-reality gap, paving the way for safer, more robust real-world AI systems of all kinds

","hash":"828a30e5bd2bcee20d26e026b8971341","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"0486e1e9-6cec-4c02-b416-8ea0afa7998d","title":"021 - AI, ML and the Reasoning Machine with Dr. Geoff Gordon","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_gordon_021.mp3","published":"2018-04-25T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Teaching computers to read, think and communicate like humans is a daunting task, but it‚Äôs one that Dr. Geoff Gordon embraces with enthusiasm and optimism. Moving from an academic role at Carnegie Mellon University, to a new role as Research Director of the Microsoft Research Lab in Montreal, Dr. Gordon embodies the current trend toward the partnership between academia and industry as we enter what many believe will be a new era of progress in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

\n

Today, Dr. Gordon gives us a brief history of AI, including his assessment of why we might see a break in the weather-pattern of AI winters, talks about how collaboration is essential to innovation in machine learning, shares his vision of the mindset it takes to tackle the biggest questions in AI, and reveals his life-long quest to make computers less‚Ä¶ well, less computer-like.

","hash":"a9199cb0f0f12b344faeceb66bff46a3","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"4f7e8355-151e-407e-b2b3-74a808fb1872","title":"020 - Getting Good VIBEs from Your Computer with Dr. Mary Czerwinski","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_czerwinski_020.mp3","published":"2018-04-18T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Emotions are fundamental to human interaction, but in a world where humans are increasingly interacting with AI systems, Dr. Mary Czerwinski, Principal Researcher and Research Manager of the Visualization and Interaction for Business and Entertainment group at Microsoft Research, believes emotions may be fundamental to our interactions with machines as well. And through her team‚Äôs work in affective computing, the quest to bring Artificial Emotional Intelligence ‚Äì or AEI ‚Äì to our computers may be closer than we think.

\n

Today, Dr. Czerwinski tells us how a cognitive psychologist found her way into the research division of the world‚Äôs largest software company, suggests that rather than trying to be productive 24/7, we should aim for Emotional Homeostasis instead, and tells us how, if we do it right, our machines could become a sort of ‚Äúemotional at-work DJ,‚Äù sensing and responding to our emotional states, and helping us to become happier and more productive at the same time.

","hash":"2f00d06eb2d78190683b9ed4ecc0dd8d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"3317ba71-54ab-41c8-b8d7-9e071d9ca21e","title":"019 - Tales from the Crypt(ography) Lab with Dr. Kristin Lauter","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_lauter_019.mp3","published":"2018-04-11T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

From ancient hieroglyphics to secret decoder rings to World War II Enigma code-makers and code-breakers, cryptography has always held a particular fascination for us. But few of us have the skills ‚Äì or can actually do the math ‚Äì to unlock the mysteries of encrypted data. Fortunately, Dr. Kristin Lauter, distinguished mathematician, founder of the Women in Numbers Network, and Principal Researcher and Research Manager for the Cryptography Group at Microsoft Research, can. And she is using her powers for good, not for evil!

\n

Today, Dr. Lauter tells us why she feels lucky¬† to do math for a living, explains the singular beauty of elliptic curves and the singular difficulty of supersingular isogeny graphs, talks about how homomorphic encryption ‚Äì part of the field of Private AI ‚Äì allows us to operate on, while still protecting, our most sensitive data, and shares her dream of one day, seeing a Grace Hopper-like conference to celebrate women in mathematics.

","hash":"43c5586bce35b426a1a8de3c93b3ddad","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"16bfad38-1de2-4080-885f-c4c167fcb8ff","title":"018 - AI for the Developing World with Dr. Ranveer Chandra","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_chandra_018.mp3","published":"2018-04-04T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

When we think about artificial intelligence and the ‚Äúworld of the future,‚Äù our vision is usually more Jetsons than Green Acres. But for Dr. Ranveer Chandra, a Principal Researcher in the Systems and Networking group at Microsoft Research, rural farms are the perfect place to realize the benefits of AI through what he calls precision agriculture, or data-driven farming.

\n

Today, in a wide-ranging interview, Dr. Chandra talks about how his research may eventually make your Wi-Fi signal stronger and your battery life longer, but also shares the story of how spending childhood summers with his grandparents in rural India inspired a line of research that could change the face of farming and help meet the food and nutrition needs of a growing global population.

","hash":"328863edfb662525b338388e6723a745","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"82f72526-2bb6-4145-b05a-c2c11dd55c7c","title":"017 - When Psychology Meets Technology with Dr. Daniel McDuff","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_mcduff_017.mp3","published":"2018-03-28T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

One of the most intriguing areas of machine learning research is affective computing, where scientists are working to bridge the gap between human emotions and computers. It is here, at the intersection of psychology and computer science, that we find Dr. Daniel McDuff, who has been designing systems, from hardware to algorithms, that can sense human behavior and respond to human emotions.

\n

Today, Dr. McDuff talks about why we need computers to understand us, outlines the pros and cons of designing emotionally sentient agents, explains the technology behind CardioLens, a pair of augmented reality glasses that can take your heartrate by looking at your face, and addresses the challenges of maintaining trust and privacy when we‚Äôre surrounded by devices that want to know not just what we‚Äôre doing, but how we‚Äôre feeling.

","hash":"29c2456119d621516f174d99ef771e40","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"979b1bae-40b8-4b4a-918d-a7ecf0e02d26","title":"016 - Building Literate Machines with Dr. Adam Trischler","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_trischler_016.mp3","published":"2018-03-21T10:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Learning to read, think and communicate effectively is part of the curriculum for every young student. But Dr. Adam Trischler, Research Manager and leader of the Machine Comprehension team at Microsoft Research Montreal, would like to make it part of the curriculum for your computer as well. And he‚Äôs working on that, using methods from machine learning, deep neural networks, and other branches of AI to close the communication gap between humans and computers.

\n

Today, Dr. Trischler talks about his dream of making literate machines, his efforts to design meta-learning algorithms that can actually learn to learn, the importance of what he calls ‚Äúfew-shot learning‚Äù in that meta-learning process, and how, through a process of one-to-many mapping in machine learning, our computers not may not only be answering our questions, but asking them as well.

\n

¬†

","hash":"65d219efa3e6a82129ae6e20212f133d","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"cafe8905-7877-405d-9dc8-92fd82daf7d1","title":"015 - Brokering Peace Talks in the Networking and Storage Arms Race with Dr. Anirudh Badam","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_badam_015.mp3","published":"2018-03-07T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

There‚Äôs a big gap between memory and storage, and Dr. Anirudh Badam, of the Systems Research Group at Microsoft Research, wants to close it. With projects like Navamem, which explores how systems can get faster and better by adopting new memory technologies, and HashCache, which brings with it the promise of storage for the next billion, he just might do it.

\n

Today, Dr. Badam discusses the historic trade-offs between volatile and non-volatile memory, shares how software-defined batteries are changing the power-supply landscape, talks about how his research is aiming for the trifecta of speed, cost and capacity in new memory technologies, and reminds us, once again, how one good high school physics teacher can inspire the next generation of scientific discovery.

\n

","hash":"0adf0df17b2b9ce732f85f82537a2974","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"dad48f83-ac3c-4524-8ae6-13a0cf1b483b","title":"014 - Keeping an Eye on AI with Dr. Kate Crawford","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_crawford_014.mp3","published":"2018-02-28T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

Artificial intelligence has captured our imagination and made many things we would have thought impossible only a few years ago seem commonplace today. But AI has also raised some challenging issues for society writ large. Enter Dr. Kate Crawford, a principal researcher at the New York City lab of Microsoft Research. Dr. Crawford, along with an illustrious group of colleagues in computer science, engineering, social science, business and law, has dedicated her research to addressing the social implications of AI, including big topics like bias, labor and automation, rights and liberties, and ethics and governance.

\n


Today, Dr. Crawford talks about both the promises and the problems of AI; why‚Äî when it comes to data ‚Äì bigger isn‚Äôt necessarily better; and how ‚Äì even in an era of increasingly complex technological advances ‚Äì we can adopt AI design principles that empower people to shape their technical tools in ways they‚Äôd like to use them most.

\n

","hash":"c839ab6a1653153bab93033634dd8203","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"134d0147-753d-4ae5-bfd8-84c633db8271","title":"013 - Machine Learning and the InnerEye for Cancer Treatment with Dr. Antonio Criminisi","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_criminisi_013.mp3","published":"2018-02-21T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

With all the sensational headlines about artificial intelligence, it‚Äôs reassuring to know that some of the world‚Äôs most brilliant minds are developing AI systems for entirely practical reasons. One of those minds belongs to Dr. Antonio Criminisi, a Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research in Cambridge, England. And one of those reasons is to help medical professionals provide better healthcare to their patients.

Today, Dr. Criminisi talks about Project InnerEye, an innovative machine learning tool that helps radiologists identify and analyze 3-D images of cancerous tumors. He also gives us some insight into his work on deep neural decision forests and tells us how gaming algorithms made their way into medical technology, moving from gamer to patient, and turning outside-in imaging‚Ä¶ inside-out.

\n

¬†

\n

","hash":"c2ac75ba71f8194a39db78163db6c2c4","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ca866cc5-2579-4ccd-b3f9-695c3b926d44","title":"012 - Code in the Classroom with Dr. Peli de Halleux","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_dehalleux_012.mp3","published":"2018-02-15T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

If you‚Äôve ever wondered if you could find the perfect combination of computer scientist‚Ä¶ and Macgyver, look no further than Dr. Peli de Halleux, principal Research Software Design Engineer at Microsoft Research. A key member of the MSR RiSE team, Peli is part of the MakeCode initiative that brings physical computing to classrooms around the country and around the world. Today, Peli talks about the Maker Movement in K-12 education, the hard work that goes on behind the scenes to deliver a ‚Äúseamless‚Äù user experience for both kids and teachers, and how to get children excited about coding through hands on experience in early computer science education.

\n

","hash":"f7a3da62dd68de4234bdefbd24b6ee28","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"cb04d894-2b7f-49a7-81a7-ed78ba177503","title":"011 - Getting LinkedIn to Data Science with Dr. Igor Perisic","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_perisic_011.mp3","published":"2018-02-07T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Big data is a big deal, and if you follow the popular technical press, you‚Äôll have heard all the metaphors: data is the new oil, the new bacon, the new currency, the new electricity. It‚Äôs even been called the new black. While data may not actually be any of these things, we can say this: in today‚Äôs networked world, data is increasingly valuable and it is essential to research, both basic and applied.

\n

Today, we welcome a special guest to the podcast. Dr. Igor Perisic is the Vice President of Engineering and Chief Data Officer at LinkedIn, the social network for business and employment. Today, Dr. Perisic talks about the key attributes of a data scientist, how AI and machine learning are helping personalize member experiences, why we should all be big open source fans, and how LinkedIn is partnering with other researchers through their innovative Economic Graph program to create economic opportunity for every member of the global workforce.

\n

All this and much more on this episode of the Microsoft Research Podcast.

","hash":"2dcd995e051e296e3b113a76cd408a19","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"257f4e2c-fac2-4228-96b3-6f8a80817e05","title":"010 - Neural Program Synthesis and the Quest to Democratize Programming with Dr. Rishabh Singh","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_Singh_010.mp3","published":"2018-01-31T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

Every day, computers take on more and more of our daily tasks. Fill in a few cells on your spreadsheet? It‚Äôll fill in the rest. Ask your car for directions? It‚Äôll get you there. Anymore, we can program computers to do almost anything. But what about programming computers to‚Ä¶ program computers? That‚Äôs a task that Dr. Rishabh Singh, and the team in the Cognition group at Microsoft Research, are tackling with Neural Program Synthesis, also known as artificial programming.

\n


Today, Dr. Singh explains how deep neural networks are already training computers to do things like take classes and grade assignments, shares how programmers can perform complicated, high-level debugging through the delightfully named process of neural fuzzing, and lays out his vision to democratize computer programming in the brave new world of Software 2.0.

\n

","hash":"777b7e2a7c0eb7a6a49e81a12ce46e7b","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"ea4f5b53-7fa3-4e6a-a164-37eb9683e9c4","title":"009 - Life at the Intersection of AI and Society with Dr. Ece Kamar","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_kamar_009.mp3","published":"2018-01-24T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

As the reality of artificial intelligence continues to capture our imagination, and critical AI systems enter our world at a rapid pace, Dr. Ece Kamar, a senior researcher in the Adaptive Systems and Interaction Group at Microsoft Research, is working to help us understand AI‚Äôs far-reaching implications, both as we use it, and as we build it.

\n


Today, Dr. Kamar talks about the complementarity between humans and machines, debunks some common misperceptions about AI, reveals how we can overcome bias and blind spots by putting humans in the AI loop, and argues convincingly that, despite everything machines can do (and they can do a lot), humans are still ‚Äúthe real deal.‚Äù

\n

","hash":"24f78affe4c76374135bba6107f65fed","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"cf92e438-38f1-4947-9522-16c47e4db9f9","title":"008 - The Future is Quantum with Dr. Krysta Svore","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_ksvore_008.mp3","published":"2018-01-17T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

If someone mentions quantum computing, and you find yourself outwardly nodding your head, but secretly shaking it, you‚Äôre in good company: some of the world‚Äôs smartest people admit they don‚Äôt really understand it either. Fortunately, some of the world‚Äôs other smartest people, like Dr. Krysta Svore, Principal Research Manager of the Microsoft Quantum ‚Äì or QuArC - group at Microsoft Research in Redmond, actually DO understand quantum computing, and are working hard to make it a reality.

\n


Today, Dr. Svore shares her passion for quantum algorithms and their potential to solve some of the world‚Äôs biggest problems, explains why Microsoft‚Äôs topological quantum bit ‚Äì or qubit ‚Äì is a game changer for quantum computing, and assures us that, although qubits live in dilution refrigerators at temperatures near absolute zero, quantum researchers can still sit in the comfort of their offices and work with the computer programmer‚Äôs equivalent of Schroedinger‚Äôs Cat.

\n

","hash":"46bf8dc1d85346503674120cdb2e2163","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"4b3f5fd9-647c-4d70-a6b4-8338a7406967","title":"007 - Functional Programming Languages and the Pursuit of Laziness with Dr. Simon Peyton Jones","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_peytonjones_007.mp3","published":"2018-01-10T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

¬†

\n

When we look at a skyscraper or a suspension bridge, a simple search engine box on a screen looks tiny by comparison. But Dr. Simon Peyton Jones would like to remind us that computer programs, with hundreds of millions of lines of code, are actually among the largest structures human beings have ever built. A principle researcher at the Microsoft Research Lab in Cambridge, England, co-developer of the programming language Haskell, and a Fellow of Britain‚Äôs Royal Society, Simon Peyton Jones has dedicated his life to this very particular kind of construction work.

\n

¬†

\n

¬†

\n

¬†

\n

Today, Dr. Peyton Jones shares his passion for functional programming research, reveals how a desire to help other researchers write and present better turned him into an unlikely YouTube star, and explains why, at least in the world of programming languages, purity is embarrassing, laziness is cool, and success should be avoided at all costs.

\n

In an era of AI breakthroughs and other exciting advances in computer science, Dr. Ben Zorn would like to remind us that behind every great technical revolution is a‚Ä¶ programming language. As a Principal Researcher and the Co-director of RiSE ‚Äì or Research in Software Engineering ‚Äì group at Microsoft Research, Dr. Zorn has dedicated his life to making sure the software that now touches nearly everything in our lives is easy, accurate, reliable and secure. Today, Dr. Zorn tells us some great stories about bugs and whales, warns us against the dumb side of ‚Äúsmart‚Äù objects, shares about his group‚Äôs attempt to scale the Everest of software security, and makes a great case that the most important programming language in the world today is‚Ä¶ the spreadsheet.

","hash":"fa523308344a3e29e282ab2a312c7520","modified":1700146234,"transcripts":[]},{"uuid":"55bef67a-0f4e-4878-85ae-f3c2bc44b235","title":"003 - Hybrid Reward Architecture and the Fall of Ms. Pac-Man with Dr. Harm van Seijen","url":"https://media.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/content.blubrry.com/microsoftresearch/msr_vanseijen_003.mp3","published":"2017-12-06T11:00:00Z","show_notes":"

If you‚Äôve ever watched King of Kong: Fistful of Quarters, you know what a big deal it is to beat a video arcade game that was designed not to lose. Most humans can‚Äôt even come close. Enter Harm van Seijen, and a team of machine learning researchers from Microsoft Maluuba in Montreal. They took on Ms. Pac-man. And won.
